data.en: Pretty soon I wanted to smoke, and asked the widow to let me. But she wouldnâ€™t. She said it was a mean practice and wasnâ€™t clean, and I must try to not do it any more. That is just the way with some people. They get down on a thing when they donâ€™t know nothing about it. Here she was a-bothering about Moses, which was no kin to her, and no use to anybody, being gone, you see, yet finding a power of fault with me for doing a thing that had some good in it. And she took snuff, too; of course that was all right, because she done it herself.

data.es: En seguida me daban ganas de fumar y le pedÃ­a permiso a la viuda. Pero no me lo daba. DecÃ­a que era una costumbre fea y sucia y que tenÃ­a que tratar de dejarlo. Eso es lo que le pasa a algunos. Le tienen manÃ­a a cosas de las que no saben nada. Lo que es ella bien que se interesaba por MoisÃ©s, que no era ni siquiera pariente suyo, y que maldito lo que le valÃ­a a nadie porque ya se habÃ­a muerto, Â¿no?, pero le parecÃ­a muy mal que yo hiciera algo que me gustaba. Y ademÃ¡s ella tomaba rapÃ©; claro que eso le parecÃ­a bien porque era ella quien se lo tomaba.
data.vi_translation: Later, when I wanted to smoke, I asked the widow for permission to smoke. She absolutely refused. She said it was a bad habit and not clean, and she tried hard to persuade me to quit smoking. There are people like that, they get involved in things they know nothing about. Just like she worried about Moses, who wasn't related to her and didn't benefit anyone, since Moses had been dead for ages. Yet she still tried to make me learn from him, thinking it was very good. But she herself smoked, of course she thought it was fine, because she was the one smoking.
data.tr_translation: After a while, I craved some tobacco and asked the widow for permission. She was adamant and wouldn't budge. She said it was a bad habit, that it made the surroundings dirty, and that I should make an effort to quit. Some people are just like that. They criticize what they don't understand. She was fixated on Moses, even though the man wasn't a relative or anything, he was of no use to anyone, he had passed away; yet she found all sorts of faults in me for engaging in a somewhat virtuous activity. Moreover, she herself used snuff, but of course, that was fine because she was the one doing it.
data.es_translation: Then I would feel like smoking and would ask the widow for permission. But she wouldn't give it to me. She said it was an ugly and dirty habit and that I had to try to quit. That's what happens to some people. They have a grudge against things they know nothing about. As for her, she was very interested in Moses, who wasn't even a relative of hers, and who was of no use to anyone because he was already dead, right? But she thought it was very bad that I did something I liked. And besides, she took snuff; of course, that seemed fine to her because she was the one taking it.

data.en: Now she had got a start, and she went on and told me all about the good place. She said all a body would have to do there was to go around all day long with a harp and sing, forever and ever. So I didnâ€™t think much of it. But I never said so. I asked her if she reckoned Tom Sawyer would go there, and she said not by a considerable sight. I was glad about that, because I wanted him and me to be together.

data.es: Entonces ella se lanzaba a contarme todo lo del sitio bueno. DecÃ­a que lo Ãºnico que se hacÃ­a allÃ­ era pasarse el dÃ­a cantando con un arpa, siempre lo mismo. AsÃ­ que no me pareciÃ³ gran cosa. Pero no dije nada. Le preguntÃ© si creÃ­a que Tom Sawyer irÃ­a allÃ­ y dijo que ni muchÃ­simo menos, y yo me alegrÃ©, porque querÃ­a estar en el mismo sitio que Ã©l.
data.vi_translation: She said that going to that place, people would spend all day wandering around singing. I didn't care about that either, but I didn't bother to say it. I asked her if Tom Sawyer could go to that good place, and she said he couldn't. Hearing that made me happy, because I wanted the two of us to stay together, not go anywhere.
data.tr_translation: Now that he had started talking, he began to tell everything he knew about the good place. According to him, the only thing a person had to do there was to wander around all day, playing the harp and singing songs, forever, without ever stopping. So, it didn't seem like a place worth going to. But I definitely didn't express this. I asked if Tom Sawyer could go there too, and it seemed he definitely couldn't. I was happy about this because I didn't want us to ever be separated.
data.es_translation: Then she would start telling me all about the good place. She said that the only thing they did there was spend the day singing with a harp, always the same thing. So it didn't seem like a big deal to me. But I didn't say anything. I asked her if she thought Tom Sawyer would go there and she said not at all, and I was glad, because I wanted to be in the same place as him.

data.en: Miss Watson she kept pecking at me, and it got tiresome and lonesome. By-and-by they fetched the niggers in and had prayers, and then everybody was off to bed. I went up to my room with a piece of candle, and put it on the table. Then I set down in a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it warnâ€™t no use. I felt so lonesome I most wished I was dead. The stars were shining, and the leaves rustled in the woods ever so mournful; and I heard an owl, away off, who-whooing about somebody that was dead, and a whippowill and a dog crying about somebody that was going to die; and the wind was trying to whisper something to me, and I couldnâ€™t make out what it was, and so it made the cold shivers run over me. Then away out in the woods I heard that kind of a sound that a ghost makes when it wants to tell about something thatâ€™s on its mind and canâ€™t make itself understood, and so canâ€™t rest easy in its grave, and has to go about that way every night grieving. I got so down-hearted and scared I did wish I had some company. Pretty soon a spider went crawling up my shoulder, and I flipped it off and it lit in the candle; and before I could budge it was all shriveled up. I didnâ€™t need anybody to tell me that that was an awful bad sign and would fetch me some bad luck, so I was scared and most shook the clothes off of me. I got up and turned around in my tracks three times and crossed my breast every time; and then I tied up a little lock of my hair with a thread to keep witches away. But I hadnâ€™t no confidence. You do that when youâ€™ve lost a horseshoe that youâ€™ve found, instead of nailing it up over the door, but I hadnâ€™t ever heard anybody say it was any way to keep off bad luck when youâ€™d killed a spider.

data.es: Un dÃ­a la seÃ±orita Watson no paraba de meterse conmigo, y yo empecÃ© a cansarme y a sentirme solo. DespuÃ©s llamaron a los negros para decir las oraciones y todo el mundo se fue a la cama. Yo me fui a mi habitaciÃ³n con un trozo de vela y lo puse en la mesa. DespuÃ©s me sentÃ© en una silla junto a la ventana y tratÃ© de pensar en algo animado, pero era inÃºtil. Me sentÃ­a tan solo que casi me daban ganas de morirme. Las estrellas brillaban y las hojas de los Ã¡rboles se rozaban con un ruido muy triste; allÃ¡ lejos se oÃ­a un bÃºho que ululaba porque se habÃ­a muerto alguien y un chotacabras y un perro que gritaban que se iba a morir alguien mÃ¡s, y el viento trataba de decirme algo y yo no entendÃ­a lo que era, de forma que me daban calofrÃ­os. DespuÃ©s, allÃ¡ en el bosque, oÃ­ ese ruido que hacen los fantasmas cuando quieren decir algo que estÃ¡n pensando y no pueden hacerse entender, de forma que no pueden descansar en la tumba y tienen que pasarse toda la noche velando. Me sentÃ­ tan desanimado y con tanto miedo que tuve ganas de compaÃ±Ã­a. Luego se me subiÃ³ una araÃ±a por el hombro y me la quitÃ© de encima y se cayÃ³ en la vela, y antes de que pudiera yo alargar la mano, ya estaba toda quemada. No hacÃ­a falta que me dijera nadie que aquello era de muy mal fario y que me iba a traer mala suerte, asÃ­ que tuve miedo y casi me quitÃ© la ropa de golpe. Me levantÃ© y di tres vueltas santiguÃ¡ndome a cada vez, y despuÃ©s me atÃ© un rizo del pelo con un hilo para que no se me acercaran las brujas. Pero no estaba nada seguro. Eso es lo que se hace cuando ha perdido uno una herradura que se ha encontrado, en vez de clavarla encima de la puerta, pero nunca le habÃ­a oÃ­do decir a nadie que fuese la forma de que no llegara la mala suerte cuando se habÃ­a matado a una araÃ±a.
data.vi_translation: Miss Watson kept pestering me like that, it was really annoying, but right after that, they called the black servants in, and everyone prayed and then went to bed. I also returned to my room, carrying a candle to place on the table. I plopped down on the chair by the window, trying to think of something fun, but I couldn't think of anything. At that moment, I felt so lonely and wished that I could just die. In the sky, the stars were twinkling. The sound of rustling leaves in the forest was incredibly mournful. I heard the distant hoot of an owl as if it were calling out to someone who had passed away, then the cry of a forest bird or a dog howling about someone who was about to die, and the wind seemed to whisper something to me that I couldn't figure out what it was trying to say. Thinking that, I shivered and felt a chill run through my body. Then after a while, from the distant forest came a sound like a ghost trying to express its worries but couldn't make anyone understand; it seemed like it couldn't rest peacefully in its grave and had to wander mournfully every night like that. Thinking that made me even more terrified, and at that moment, I wished there was someone sitting next to me. Suddenly, a spider jumped onto my shoulder from somewhere, crawling on my shirt, I quickly flicked it off with my hand, and it shot straight into the burning candle, and before I could pull it out, it was dead. At that moment, I didn't need anyone to tell me that it was a bad omen and that I would face misfortune, I was already very scared and frantically shook my clothes. I jumped up, spun around three or four times, and then made the sign of the cross many times. Then I took a string and tied up my hair to make a charm to ward off evil spirits. But then I didn't believe it either. This was the custom when someone lost something, after finding it, they were supposed to tie a bow at the front door; but I had never heard anyone say that doing so would prevent bad luck after killing a spider.
data.tr_translation: While Mrs. Watson was listing her advice and scoldings one after another, I felt increasingly exhausted and lonely. Soon after, they brought in the black slaves and started praying, then everyone retired to their beds. I took a candle and went to my room, placing the candle on the table. I sat on a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it didn't work at all. I felt so utterly alone that I wished I were dead. The stars were shining brightly and the leaves in the forest were rustling mournfully, I heard an owl hooting in the distance; it was saying puuu-huuu for someone who had died; also, a whip-poor-will and a dog were howling to announce that someone nearby was going to die; the wind was trying to whisper something to me, but I couldn't understand what it was, so a cold shiver ran down my spine. Then, from the depths of the forest, I heard a sound like that made by ghosts who, unable to convey their troubles, leave their graves in despair and wander around every evening in torment. I was so demoralized and so scared that I wished someone were with me. Soon after, a spider started climbing up my shoulder, and when I flicked it, it fell onto the candle; before I could even move, it was scorched. No one needed to tell me that this was a terribly bad omen and would bring me bad luck, I started trembling like a leaf out of fear. I stood up and turned around three times, making the sign of the cross each time; then I tied a piece of string to a lock of my hair to keep the witches away. But I still didn't feel at ease. You know how when you find a horseshoe but lose it before you can nail it above the door, you do this, but I had never heard of anything you could do to ward off bad luck when you kill a spider.
data.es_translation: One day Miss Watson wouldn't stop picking on me, and I started to get tired and feel lonely. Then they called the slaves to say prayers and everyone went to bed. I went to my room with a piece of candle and put it on the table. Then I sat in a chair by the window and tried to think of something cheerful, but it was useless. I felt so lonely that I almost wanted to die. The stars were shining and the leaves of the trees were rustling with a very sad sound; far away an owl was hooting because someone had died and a whippoorwill and a dog were crying that someone else was going to die, and the wind was trying to tell me something and I couldn't understand what it was, so I got chills. Then, out in the forest, I heard that noise ghosts make when they want to say something they're thinking and can't make themselves understood, so they can't rest in the grave and have to stay up all night. I felt so discouraged and scared that I wanted company. Then a spider climbed up my shoulder and I brushed it off and it fell into the candle, and before I could reach out, it was already all burned up. No one needed to tell me that this was very bad luck and that it was going to bring me misfortune, so I got scared and almost tore my clothes off. I got up and walked three circles making the sign of the cross each time, and then I tied a lock of my hair with a thread so that witches wouldn't come near me. But I wasn't sure at all. That's what you do when you've lost a horseshoe you found, instead of nailing it above the door, but I had never heard anyone say it was the way to keep bad luck away when you had killed a spider.

data.en: I set down again, a-shaking all over, and got out my pipe for a smoke; for the house was all as still as death now, and so the widow wouldnâ€™t know. Well, after a long time I heard the clock away off in the town go boomâ€”boomâ€”boomâ€”twelve licks; and all still againâ€”stiller than ever. Pretty soon I heard a twig snap down in the dark amongst the treesâ€”something was a stirring. I set still and listened. Directly I could just barely hear a â€œme-yow! me-yow!â€ down there. That was good! Says I, â€œme-yow! me-yow!â€ as soft as I could, and then I put out the light and scrambled out of the window on to the shed. Then I slipped down to the ground and crawled in among the trees, and, sure enough, there was Tom Sawyer waiting for me.

data.vi_translation: I sat down on the chair again, feeling restless and uneasy. I took out a cigarette to smoke, because by now the house was as silent as death, and the widow had no idea what was going on. Then after a while, quite a long time, I heard the distant clock chime - bong - bong - bong, striking twelve times, and then everything was quieter than ever. After a moment, I suddenly heard the sound of a dry branch breaking in the dark bushes - it seemed like something was moving. I sat silently and immediately heard clearly the sound of a meow coming from that direction. Great! I softly responded with a meow, then extinguished the candle, climbed out the window, headed towards the darkness, quickly slid down to the ground, and slipped into the bushes. It was indeed Tom Sawyer waiting for me there.
data.tr_translation: Shivering violently, I sat down again and took out my pipe to smoke; because now there was a deathly silence in the house, and not even the spirit of the widow would hear me smoking. Anyway, after a long time, I heard the town clock strike twelve with a tonk-tonk-tonk, and then silence fell again, the surroundings were even quieter than before. Shortly after, I heard a branch break in the darkness among the trees â€“ something was stirring. I sat quietly and listened intently. From below, a faint â€œMeow! Meow!â€ sound was heard. That was good! I also said as quietly as possible, â€œMeow! Meow!â€, then blew out the candle and stepped out onto the veranda through the window. Slipping down from the veranda, I started crawling among the trees and, of course, found Tom Sawyer waiting for me there.
data.es_translation: I sat down again, all trembling, and took out the pipe to smoke, because the house was now quieter than a tomb, so the widow wouldn't find out. Well, after a long time I heard the town clock start to chime: boom... boom... boom... twelve strokes and everything remained just as calm, quieter than ever. Shortly after, I heard a branch snap in the darkness among the trees: something was moving. I straightened up and listened. Soon I barely heard a "meow! meow!" down there. Great! I went and said "meow! meow!" as low as I could and then turned off the light and climbed down the window to the shed. Then I dropped to the ground and crawled among the trees, and of course, there was Tom Sawyer waiting for me.

We lit candles and then crawled on. After about two hundred yards, we reached the cave entrance. Tom fumbled around for a way, and then suddenly he slipped under a wall where no one would have guessed there was a hole. We squeezed through a very narrow passage and came to a place that looked like a room, damp and cold. Then everyone stopped there. Tom said:

We lit the candles and crawled inside. After moving forward for about two hundred meters, the cave widened. After checking some passages, Tom disappeared from sight by going under a wall that didn't appear to have a hole from the outside. We also passed through a narrow passage and emerged into a very damp, airless, cool chamber and stopped. Tom began to speak:

data.en: Everybody was willing. So Tom got out a sheet of paper that he had wrote the oath on, and read it. It swore every boy to stick to the band, and never tell any of the secrets; and if anybody done anything to any boy in the band, whichever boy was ordered to kill that person and his family must do it, and he mustnâ€™t eat and he mustnâ€™t sleep till he had killed them and hacked a cross in their breasts, which was the sign of the band. And nobody that didnâ€™t belong to the band could use that mark, and if he did he must be sued; and if he done it again he must be killed. And if anybody that belonged to the band told the secrets, he must have his throat cut, and then have his carcass burnt up and the ashes scattered all around, and his name blotted off of the list with blood and never mentioned again by the gang, but have a curse put on it and be forgot forever.

Cada uno de los chicos juraba ser fiel a la banda y no contar nunca ninguno de sus secretos, y si alguien le hacÃ­a algo a algÃºn chico de la banda, el chico al que se le ordenara matar a esa persona y su familia tenÃ­a que hacerlo, y no podÃ­a comer ni dormir hasta haberlos matado a todos y marcarles con el cuchillo una cruz en el pecho, que era la seÃ±al de la banda. Nadie que no perteneciese a la banda podÃ­a utilizar esa seÃ±al, y si lo hacÃ­a habÃ­a que denunciarlo, y si volvÃ­a a hacerlo, habÃ­a que matarlo. Y si alguien que pertenecÃ­a a la banda contaba los secretos, habÃ­a que cortarle el cuello y despuÃ©s quemar su cadÃ¡ver, tirar las cenizas por todas partes y borrar su nombre de la lista con sangre, y nadie de la banda podÃ­a volver a mencionar su nombre, sino que quedaba maldito y habÃ­a que olvidarlo para siempre.
data.vi_translation: Anyone who hears it will like it. Tom took out a piece of paper on which he had written the oath and read it aloud. The oath stated that all those who joined the group must remain loyal and not disclose any secrets; and if anyone harmed a member in any way, that member would be ordered to kill the offender and their entire family, and must carry out the order; and they would not be allowed to eat or sleep until they had killed them and marked their chest with a cross, which was the group's unique symbol. Anyone not in the group was not allowed to use that symbol. If someone else used it, they would be prosecuted, and if they reoffended, they would be executed. If anyone in the group disclosed a secret, they would be beheaded, their body would be burned, their name would be erased from the list with blood, and they would never be mentioned again, they would be cursed and forever forgotten.
data.tr_translation: Everyone was already willing since yesterday. Tom took out the paper on which he had written the oath and began to read. According to what was written, each child would remain loyal to the gang and would not tell their secrets to anyone; if someone harmed one of the children in the gang, the child who was given the order would have to kill the person who caused the harm and their family, and it was forbidden to eat or sleep without carving the cross mark, which was the gang's symbol, on their chests after killing them all. No one who did not belong to the gang could use this cross mark; if they did, they would be sued, and if they used it again, they would have to be killed. If any member of the gang revealed the secrets, their throat would be cut, their body would be burned, and after their ashes were scattered in all directions, their name on the list would be covered in blood. No one from the gang would ever mention their name again, they would be cursed and forgotten forever.
data.es_translation: Everyone wanted to. Then Tom took out a sheet of paper on which he had written the oath and read it aloud. Each of the boys swore to be loyal to the gang and never to reveal any of its secrets, and if someone did something to any boy in the gang, the boy who was ordered to kill that person and their family had to do it, and could not eat or sleep until he had killed them all and marked a cross on their chest with a knife, which was the gang's symbol. No one who did not belong to the gang could use that symbol, and if they did, they had to be reported, and if they did it again, they had to be killed. And if someone who belonged to the gang revealed the secrets, their throat had to be cut and then their body burned, the ashes scattered everywhere, and their name erased from the list with blood, and no one in the gang could ever mention their name again, as they would be cursed and had to be forgotten forever.

data.vi_translation: Tom Sawyer interrupted: - Taking cattle and things like that is not robbery, it's just petty theft. We are not thieves. That's not our style. We are bandits; on the main road, we stop vehicles, wear masks, kill people, and rob passengers of their watches and money.
data.tr_translation: Stealing cattle and similar things is not robbery, it's theft," said Tom Sawyer. "We are not thieves. Theft is against the code. We are highwaymen. We put on our masks, stop mail and stagecoaches, kill people and take their watches and money."
data.es_translation: Stealing cattle and those things isn't real stealing; those are rustlers â€”says Tom Sawyerâ€”. We are not rustlers. That's not elegant. We are highwaymen. We stop stagecoaches and carriages on the road, with masks on, and kill people and take their watches and money.

data.vi_translation: In the morning, Miss Watson lectured me about my dirty clothes; as for the widow, she didn't scold me at all but just quietly cleaned the stains. Seeing that, I felt remorseful and thought that if possible, I should behave well for a while. Then Miss Watson pulled me into the small room to pray. But it was useless. She told me I had to pray every day, and if I did, I would get whatever I wanted. But that wasn't true at all, I had tried many times. Once, I got a fishing rod but no hook. Without a hook, I couldn't do anything. I diligently prayed four times but it was useless. I then asked Miss Watson to pray for me, but she called me crazy. She didn't explain why, and I couldn't understand it at all.
data.tr_translation: In the morning, I got a good scolding from our Miss Watson because of the state of my clothes; but the widow didn't get mad at all, though she looked so sad while cleaning the grease and dirt that I decided to try to behave for a while if I could. Then Miss Watson took me into the closet and prayed, but it still didn't do any good. She told me that if I prayed every day, I would get everything I wanted. But I didn't get anything. I tried. Once, I had a fishing line, but no hook. Without a hook, the line was useless. I tried praying for a fishing hook three or four times, but it never worked. Then one day, I asked Miss Watson to try it for me, but she said I was a fool. She never explained why, and I couldn't make any sense of it.
data.es_translation: WELL, in the morning old Miss Watson gave me a good scolding about the clothes, but the widow didn't scold me, she just cleaned the stains and mud, and she seemed so sad that I thought if I could, I would behave well for a while. Then Miss Watson took me to the parlor to pray, but nothing happened. She told me to pray every day and that everything I asked for would be given to me. But it wasn't true. I tried. Once I got a fishing line, but without hooks. Without hooks it was useless to me. I tried to get the hooks three or four times, but I don't know why it didn't work. So one day I asked Miss Watson to try for me, but she said I was silly. She never explained why and I could never understand it.

data.en: I thought all this over for two or three days, and then I reckoned I would see if there was anything in it. I got an old tin lamp and an iron ring, and went out in the woods and rubbed and rubbed till I sweat like an Injun, calculating to build a palace and sell it; but it warnâ€™t no use, none of the genies come. So then I judged that all that stuff was only just one of Tom Sawyerâ€™s lies. I reckoned he believed in the A-rabs and the elephants, but as for me I think different. It had all the marks of a Sunday-school.

data.vi_translation: I had to think about this for a few days. I planned to see if there was anything real in it. I went to find an old tin lamp and an iron ring, took them out to the forest, and rubbed and rubbed until I was sweating, having already planned to build a castle to sell. But it was useless, no genie appeared. After that, I concluded that all those absurd stories were just one of Tom Sawyer's many lies. I was sure he believed there were real Arabs and elephants; but as for me, I thought differently. Because clearly, they were just a bunch of students from the local school.
data.tr_translation: I thought about this issue for two or three days, then I decided to see for myself whether it was real or not. I took an old tin lamp and an iron ring and went to the forest to start rubbing them. I kept rubbing until I was drenched in sweat with the hope of having a palace built and then selling it, but it was all in vain; none of the genies appeared. At that point, I concluded that all of this was just Tom Sawyer's inventions. He probably believed in Arabs and elephants, but I thought differently. In my opinion, the spirit of Sunday school was infused into everything he told.
data.es_translation: I kept thinking about all that for two or three days and then decided to try, to see if it was true or not. I took an old tin lamp and an iron ring to the forest and started rubbing until I was sweating like an Indian, figuring I would build a palace to sell it; but nothing, no genie came. Then I thought that all that was just one of Tow Sawyer's lies. I supposed he believed in the Arabs and the elephants, but I don't think the same as him. That seemed like a Sunday school thing.

data.vi_translation: The next day, he was completely drunk, stumbled to old chief Thatcher's house, intending to force him to hand over all the money. But it was useless; then he swore he would bring the old chief to justice.
data.tr_translation: The next day, with a drunken mind, he went to Judge Thatcher's door and tried to scare him into giving the money, and when that didn't work, he swore he would sue him.
data.es_translation: The next day he was drunk and went to see Judge Thatcher, to bother him trying to get him to give him the money, but he didn't succeed, and then he swore he was going to make the law force him.

data.en: The judge and the widow went to law to get the court to take me away from him and let one of them be my guardian; but it was a new judge that had just come, and he didnâ€™t know the old man; so he said courts mustnâ€™t interfere and separate families if they could help it; said heâ€™d druther not take a child away from its father. So Judge Thatcher and the widow had to quit on the business.

data.es: El juez y la viuda fueron a la ley para que el tribunal le quitase la custodia y que uno de ellos fuera mi tutor, pero habÃ­a llegado un juez nuevo y no conocÃ­a a mi viejo, asÃ­ que dijo que los tribunales no debÃ­an intervenir para separar familias si podÃ­an evitarlo; dijo que preferÃ­a no separar a un hijo de su padre. AsÃ­ que el juez Thatcher y la viuda tuvieron que renunciar al asunto.
data.vi_translation: The village chief and the widow went to court to get me out of my father's hands and to have the court assign one of them as my guardian. But there was a new judge who had just arrived, who didn't know what kind of person my father was, and said that the court had no right to interfere in separating families, but rather should reunite them, and certainly couldn't force a child to be away from their father. So, the village chief Thatcher and the widow had to give up.
data.tr_translation: The judge and the widow lady applied to the court to rescue me from him and to appoint one of them as my legal guardian; but at that time a new judge had been appointed and he did not know my father: Therefore, he said that it was not right for the courts to intervene and separate families unless absolutely necessary. He did not want to deprive a child of his father. Judge Thatcher and the widow lady had to reluctantly give up on this matter.
data.es_translation: The judge and the widow went to court to have the custody taken away and for one of them to become my guardian, but a new judge had arrived and he didn't know my old one, so he said that the courts should not intervene to separate families if they could avoid it; he said he preferred not to separate a child from his father. So Judge Thatcher and the widow had to give up the matter.

data.en: It was kind of lazy and jolly, laying off comfortable all day, smoking and fishing, and no books nor study. Two months or more run along, and my clothes got to be all rags and dirt, and I didnâ€™t see how Iâ€™d ever got to like it so well at the widowâ€™s, where you had to wash, and eat on a plate, and comb up, and go to bed and get up regular, and be forever bothering over a book, and have old Miss Watson pecking at you all the time. I didnâ€™t want to go back no more. I had stopped cussing, because the widow didnâ€™t like it; but now I took to it again because pap hadnâ€™t no objections. It was pretty good times up in the woods there, take it all around.

data.es: Todo era muy tranquilo y se pasaba bien, tumbado todo el dÃ­a, fumando y pescando, sin libros ni estudios. Pasaron dos meses o mÃ¡s y toda la ropa se me hizo jirones y se me puso sucia, y no entendÃ­a cÃ³mo me habÃ­a gustado estar en casa de la viuda, donde habÃ­a que lavarse y comer en un plato y peinarse e irse a la cama y levantarse a horas fijas y pasarse la vida con un tostÃ³n de libro mientras la vieja seÃ±orita Watson se metÃ­a con uno todo el tiempo. Ya no querÃ­a volver. HabÃ­a dejado de decir palabrotas porque a la viuda no le gustaban, pero ahora volvÃ­a a decirlas porque padre no le veÃ­a nada de malo. Lo pasÃ© bastante bien allÃ­ en el bosque, si se tiene todo en cuenta.
data.vi_translation: It was a kind of laziness that was quite pleasant. All day long, just relaxing, smoking, fishing, no books and no studying at all. About two months later, my clothes were dirty and tattered. I didn't think that when I was living with the widow, I ever liked it as much as this. Because there, I had to wash clothes. I had to eat with bowls and plates, comb my hair, go to bed and get up on time, always worry about books and notebooks, and listen to Miss Watson's nagging all day long. I didn't feel like going back to that place anymore. Before, I had stopped using bad language because the widow didn't like it. But now, I started again because my father didn't forbid it at all. Living in the forest was truly enjoyable, everywhere was just as delightful.
data.tr_translation: Spending the whole day smoking tobacco and fishing, lying around without studying at all, both made a person lazy and brought them joy. After about two months, all the clothes I had on turned into filthy rags. I no longer knew why I loved the widow's house so much, where I constantly washed, ate from a plate, combed my hair, went to bed and got up on time, constantly dealt with books, and was always scolded by our Miss Watson. I didn't want to go back. I had stopped swearing because the widow didn't like it, but I had started again since my father didn't object. To be honest, I was having quite a good time in the forest.
data.es_translation: Everything was very peaceful and it was enjoyable, lying around all day, smoking and fishing, without books or studies. Two months or more passed and all my clothes became tattered and dirty, and I didn't understand how I had liked being at the widow's house, where you had to wash yourself and eat from a plate and comb your hair and go to bed and get up at fixed times and spend your life with a boring book while old Miss Watson was always nagging at you. I no longer wanted to go back. I had stopped cursing because the widow didn't like it, but now I started cursing again because father didn't see anything wrong with it. All things considered, I had a pretty good time there in the forest.

data.en: â€œCall this a govment! why, just look at it and see what itâ€™s like. Hereâ€™s the law a-standing ready to take a manâ€™s son away from himâ€”a manâ€™s own son, which he has had all the trouble and all the anxiety and all the expense of raising. Yes, just as that man has got that son raised at last, and ready to go to work and begin to do suthinâ€™ for him and give him a rest, the law up and goes for him. And they call that govment! That ainâ€™t all, nuther. The law backs that old Judge Thatcher up and helps him to keep me out oâ€™ my property. Hereâ€™s what the law does: The law takes a man worth six thousand dollars and upâ€™ards, and jams him into an old trap of a cabin like this, and lets him go round in clothes that ainâ€™t fitten for a hog. They call that govment! A man canâ€™t get his rights in a govment like this. Sometimes Iâ€™ve a mighty notion to just leave the country for good and all. Yes, and I told â€™em so; I told old Thatcher so to his face. Lots of â€™em heard me, and can tell what I said. Says I, for two cents Iâ€™d leave the blamed country and never come a-near it agin. Themâ€™s the very words. I says look at my hatâ€”if you call it a hatâ€”but the lid raises up and the rest of it goes down till itâ€™s below my chin, and then it ainâ€™t rightly a hat at all, but more like my head was shoved up through a jint oâ€™ stove-pipe. Look at it, says Iâ€”such a hat for me to wearâ€”one of the wealthiest men in this town if I could git my rights.

data.es: â€”Â¡Y a esto lo llaman gobierno!, pues no hay mÃ¡s que mirar para ver lo que es. Hacen una ley para quitarle a un hombre su hijo: su propio hijo, con todo el trabajo y todas las preocupaciones y los gastos que me ha llevado criarlo. SÃ­, y justo cuando ese hombre por fin ha criado a su hijo que ya estÃ¡ en edad de ponerse a trabajar y empezar a hacer algo por Ã©l para que pueda descansar, va la ley y se lo quita. Â¡Y a eso lo llaman gobierno! Y no es todo. La ley apoya a ese viejo del juez Thatcher y le ayuda a quitarme mis bienes. Fijarse lo que hace la ley: la ley agarra a un hombre que tiene seis mil dÃ³lares o mÃ¡s y lo encierra en una vieja cabaÃ±a como Ã©sta y deja que vaya vestido con una ropa que no es digna ni de un cerdo. Â¡Y a eso lo llaman gobierno! Con un gobierno asÃ­ no hay forma de que uno tenga derechos. A veces me da la tentaciÃ³n de marcharme del paÃ­s para siempre. SÃ­, y se lo he dicho; se lo he dicho al viejo Thatcher a la cara. Me lo oyeron montones de personas y pueden decir que lo dije. Voy y digo: Â«Por dos centavos me irÃ­a de este maldito paÃ­s y no volverÃ­a ni aunque me pagasenÂ». Eso fue exactamente lo que dije; Â«Mirar este sombrero â€”si es que se le puede llamar sombreroâ€”, que se le levanta la tapa y el resto se baja hasta que se cae debajo de la barbilla y ya no es ni un sombrero ni nada, sino mÃ¡s bien como si me hubieran metido la cabeza en un tubo de chimenea. MirarloÂ», voy y digo: Â«Vaya un sombrero para un tipo como yo, uno de los hombres mÃ¡s ricos de este pueblo si me se reconocieran mis derechosÂ».
data.vi_translation: - Huh! And you call that a government? Let's see what it has done. This is the law. The law is ready to take people away, huh? People have to work hard and worry so much to raise their stepchildren. Yes, that's right, people raise their children to grow up, and when they are about to start working to earn something to support their parents, this is what happens. The law is made to help people. And you call that a government! It's not a government at all. The law supports that old Thatcher and helps him take all my property? Here, this is what the law does; the law takes six thousand dollars from people and forces them into an old trap in a house like this, making them wander around in clothes not even fit for pigs. And you call that a government. With a government like this, people have no rights at all. Sometimes I think it's better to just leave this place for good. Yes, I told everyone that, I said it straight to Thatcher's face. Many people heard me say that and can confirm that I said it. I said just give me two cents and I would leave this cursed place immediately and never come back. And everyone says the same thing. Here, look at my hat - if you can even call it a hat, the top pops off, and the rest falls down to my chin. How can you call that a hat anymore? Putting my head in the hat is like sticking it into a chimney. Here, look, this is how my hat fits. If I had all my rights, I would be one of the richest people in the province...
data.tr_translation: â€œSuch a government should not exist! Just standing still and looking is enough to see what it is. This so-called law is ready to take a man's son away from him â€“ his own son, whom he has endured countless troubles and hardships to raise. When the poor man finally thinks he has raised his child, and expects to find a job and take care of him, and perhaps find some peace for himself, the laws suddenly stand against him. Is this what a government should be like! No, it shouldn't be like this. The law supports our Judge Thatcher and helps him take my property away from me. This is what the laws are good for. Their so-called law strips a man worth six thousand dollars to the bone and stuffs him into such old shacks, making him wear clothes that even pigs wouldn't wear. Is this a government! Who can seek their rights in this government? Sometimes I think of leaving this country and never coming back. I told them this too. I even told it to our Thatcher's face. Several men heard me, they all witnessed it. I said I would even pay money to leave this country and never come back. That's exactly what I said. Look at this hat of mine, I saidâ€¦ can this even be called a hatâ€¦ its top opens up and it comes down to my chin. It's no longer a hat, it's as if my head is stuck in a stove pipe. Look here, I said, this is the kind of hat you make me wear, one of the richest men in town. Oh, if only I could get my rights.
data.es_translation: â€”And they call this a government! Just look around to see what it really is. They make a law to take a man's son away from him: his own son, with all the work, worries, and expenses it took to raise him. Yes, and just when that man has finally raised his son to the age where he can start working and doing something for him so he can rest, the law comes and takes him away. And they call that a government! And that's not all. The law sides with that old Judge Thatcher and helps him take away my property. Look at what the law does: the law grabs a man who has six thousand dollars or more and locks him up in an old cabin like this and lets him wear clothes that aren't even fit for a pig. And they call that a government! With a government like that, there's no way a man can have rights. Sometimes I'm tempted to leave the country for good. Yes, and I've said it; I've said it to old Thatcher's face. Lots of people heard me, and they can say I said it. I go and say: "For two cents I'd leave this damned country and never come back even if they paid me." That's exactly what I said; "Look at this hatâ€”if you can even call it a hatâ€”it lifts up at the top and falls down until it slips under my chin and it's not even a hat anymore, but more like they stuck my head in a chimney pipe. Look at it," I go and say: "What a hat for a guy like me, one of the richest men in this town if my rights were recognized."

data.en: I took the axe and smashed in the door. I beat it and hacked it considerable a-doing it. I fetched the pig in, and took him back nearly to the table and hacked into his throat with the axe, and laid him down on the ground to bleed; I say ground because it was groundâ€”hard packed, and no boards. Well, next I took an old sack and put a lot of big rocks in itâ€”all I could dragâ€”and I started it from the pig, and dragged it to the door and through the woods down to the river and dumped it in, and down it sunk, out of sight. You could easy see that something had been dragged over the ground. I did wish Tom Sawyer was there; I knowed he would take an interest in this kind of business, and throw in the fancy touches. Nobody could spread himself like Tom Sawyer in such a thing as that.

data.vi_translation: I took the axe and struck the door with a strong blow. It took a lot of hitting, quite a long time to break the door. I dragged the pig inside, pulled it near the table, then struck the pig's neck with an axe, leaving it on the ground for a while to let the blood flow out. I say ground because it was real ground, just compacted earth, not wood flooring, then I grabbed an old bag, filled it with large pebbles, heavy enough for me to drag, then from the pig's location, I dragged the bag of pebbles to the door, through the woods to the riverbank, and threw it down there. The bag of pebbles sank, disappearing completely. Anyone could see that something had been dragged along the ground. I wished Tom Sawyer were here at this moment because I knew he would love this kind of thing and would add more details to make it even more thrilling. For such stories, no one could boast more than Tom Sawyer.
data.tr_translation: I took the axe and broke the door â€“ I had hit it with all my strength and shattered the planks. I took the pig inside and brought it to a spot near the table, then cut its throat with the axe. I left it on the ground so the blood could drain â€“ I say ground because there was no flooring, no planks laid, just the compacted earth beneath. Then I took an old sack and filled it with large stones â€“ just enough that I could still drag it. I dragged the sack from where the pig was, through the door, down to the riverbank among the trees, and left it in the water there. It immediately sank and disappeared from sight. It was clear that something had been dragged on the ground. I wish Tom Sawyer had been with me... I knew very well how keen you were on such schemes, if he saw it now, who knows what cunning ideas would come to his mind. I've never seen anyone in my life whose mind worked as sharply as Tom Sawyer's in such matters.
data.es_translation: I grabbed the axe and jumped over the door. I smashed it as much as I could. I brought the pig inside and dragged it almost to the table, then I cut its throat with the axe and left it on the ground to bleed; I say on the ground because it was dirt: compacted and without floorboards. Then I took an old sack and filled it with large stones â€”all that I could dragâ€”, starting where the pig was, and dragged it to the door and through the woods to the river, where I threw it; it sank and disappeared. It was easy to see that something had been dragged across the ground. I thought that I wished Tom Sawyer had been there; I knew he was interested in these things and that he would add the precise details. Nobody knew how to embellish things like Tom Sawyer in a matter like this.

data.vi_translation: I also didn't have to spend much time explaining to him that I wasn't dead. I was so happy to meet Jim here. Now I am no longer lonely. I told him that if he went and told everyone that I was here, I wouldn't be afraid. I kept talking, but he just sat there looking at me without saying a word. Then I told him.

I catched a good big catfish, too, and Jim cleaned him with his knife, and fried him.

data.vi_translation: Both of us went to the place where the canoe was hidden. Then, while Jim started a fire on a patch of grass among the surrounding trees, I went to get the bacon and coffee, the coffee pot; the pan, then the sugar, and the tin cups. The black man was very frightened because he thought that all these things were the result of some witchcraft. I caught a big fish, and Jim used his pocket knife to clean it and then fried it.
data.tr_translation: So we went to where the cannon was, and while we were lighting a fire in a grassy area among those trees, I quickly took out cornmeal, bacon, coffee, a coffee pot, a pan, sugar, and a tin cup. Jim was astonished because he thought I had done it all by magic. I also caught a big catfish, and Jim cleaned it with his knife and fried the fish.
data.es_translation: So we went to where the canoe was, and while he was setting up the bonfire in a clearing in the grass among the trees, I went to get flour and bacon and coffee, and a coffee pot and a pan and sugar and some tin cups, and the black man was very astonished, because he thought I did everything by witchcraft. I also caught a good catfish and Jim cleaned it with his knife and fried it.

data.en: When breakfast was ready we lolled on the grass and eat it smoking hot. Jim laid it in with all his might, for he was most about starved. Then when we had got pretty well stuffed, we laid off and lazied. By-and-by Jim says:

Bueno, una noche me acerco a la puerta muy tarde y la puerta no estaba cerrada del todo y oigo a la moza vieja que dice a la viuda que me va a vender en Orleans, aunque no querÃ­a, pero que me podÃ­a sacar ochocientos dÃ³lares, y era tanto dinero que no podÃ­a resistirse. data.vi_translation: Here, like this, buddy. My aunt, that is Mrs. Watson, keeps tormenting me all day and treating me terribly. But she still says she won't take me down to Orleans to sell me. But I noticed that there was a new black slave trader around here last night, and I started to get scared. Then one late night, I crawled to the door, which wasn't fully closed, and I heard her telling the widow that she would take me to Orleans to sell, but she didn't want to sell me right away because she could still get eight hundred dollars more for me. With such a large amount of money, she probably couldn't resist. The widow wanted to tell her not to do that. But at that moment, I didn't wait to hear what happened next. I ran away quickly. I'm telling you the truth.
data.tr_translation: â€œAlright, hereâ€™s how it happened. My owner, that is, Miss Watson, was constantly scolding me and treating me badly, but she always said, â€˜I wonâ€™t sell you to those folks in Orleans.â€™ But in recent days, I noticed a slave trader wandering around our place, and I started to get suspicious. Anyway, one night, late at night, as I was passing by a door left ajar, I heard our old master telling the widow that he was going to sell me to those folks in Orleans; he didnâ€™t actually want to sell me, but he could get eight hundred dollars for me, which was too much money to resist. The widow tried to talk him out of it, but I didnâ€™t stay to hear more. I ran away immediately, just like that.
data.es_translation: â€”Well, look, it happened like this. The old maid, that is, Miss Watson, spends her time picking on me and treats me very badly, but she always said she wouldn't sell me in Orleans. But I noticed that there was a slave trader who spent a lot of time around the house, and I started to get nervous. Well, one night I go up to the door very late, and the door wasn't completely closed, and I hear the old maid telling the widow that she's going to sell me in Orleans, even though she didn't want to, but that she could get eight hundred dollars for me, and it was so much money that she couldn't resist. The widow tried to make her promise not to, but I didn't wait to hear the rest. I assure you, I left as fast as I could.

data.en: Some young birds come along, flying a yard or two at a time and lighting. Jim said it was a sign it was going to rain. He said it was a sign when young chickens flew that way, and so he reckoned it was the same way when young birds done it. I was going to catch some of them, but Jim wouldnâ€™t let me. He said it was death. He said his father laid mighty sick once, and some of them catched a bird, and his old granny said his father would die, and he did.

Dijo que eso significaba cuando lo hacÃ­an los pollitos, asÃ­ que pensaba que era lo mismo cuando lo hacÃ­an los pajaritos. Yo iba a cazar algunos, pero Jim no me dejÃ³. Dijo que traÃ­a la muerte. data.vi_translation: A few young birds here flew over, only flying short distances of a few yards before perching again. Jim said it was a sign of rain. He said that when chicks fly erratically, it means rain is coming, so seeing birds fly like that also made him predict rain. I intended to catch a few birds, but Jim wouldn't let me. He said doing so would bring death. He said that his father once fell seriously ill, and when someone else caught birds, his father told him that doing so would cause his father to die. And indeed, he died.
data.tr_translation: Young birds appeared around, flying a meter or two and landing on branches. Jim said this was a sign that it would rain. When chicks flew like this, it meant rain, so he guessed it would mean the same for other young birds as well. I wanted to catch a few, but Jim didn't allow it. He said it was akin to death. Once, his father had gotten very sick, and when someone caught a bird, his old grandmother said his father would die, and indeed, he did.
data.es_translation: Some little birds passed by, flying a yard or two each time and then landing again. Jim said it was a sign that it was going to rain. He said that it meant the same thing when chicks did it, so he thought it was the same when little birds did it. I was going to hunt some, but Jim didn't let me. He said it brought death. He said that his father got very sick once and someone in his family caught a bird and his grandmother said that his father would die and that's what happened.

data.en: And Jim said you mustnâ€™t count the things you are going to cook for dinner, because that would bring bad luck. The same if you shook the table-cloth after sundown. And he said if a man owned a beehive and that man died, the bees must be told about it before sun-up next morning, or else the bees would all weaken down and quit work and die. Jim said bees wouldnâ€™t sting idiots; but I didnâ€™t believe that, because I had tried them lots of times myself, and they wouldnâ€™t sting me.

data.es: Y Jim dijo que no habÃ­a que contar las cosas que iba uno a cocinar para la cena, porque traÃ­a mala suerte. Lo mismo que si se sacudÃ­a el mantel despuÃ©s de anochecer. Y dijo que si un hombre tenÃ­a una colmena y se morÃ­a ese hombre, habÃ­a que decÃ­rselo a las abejas antes de que volviera a salir el sol a la maÃ±ana siguiente, porque si no las abejas se ponÃ­an enfermas y dejaban de trabajar y se morÃ­an. data.vi_translation: Jim also said that one should not plan ahead what to cook for dinner, as it would bring bad luck. And shaking out the tablecloth at sunset is the same. He also said that when the sun rises the next morning, the bees would already know. If not, the bees would fall ill, refuse to work, and eventually die. Jim said that bees never sting fools. But I don't believe that, because I've tried it several times and still haven't been stung.
data.tr_translation: Also, Jim said that you shouldn't count the things you eat in the evening, because it brings bad luck. The same thing happens if you shake the tablecloth after sunset. And if a man has a beehive, when that man dies, you need to inform the bees before the sun rises the next morning, otherwise all the bees will weaken, stop working, and die. Jim also said that bees don't sting fools, but I didn't believe it, because I had dealt with them many times and they hadn't stung me.
data.es_translation: And Jim said that one shouldn't talk about the things one was going to cook for dinner, because it brought bad luck. The same as if one shook the tablecloth after nightfall. And he said that if a man had a beehive and that man died, one had to tell the bees before the sun rose again the next morning, because if not, the bees would get sick and stop working and die. Jim said that bees didn't sting idiots, but I didn't believe it, because I had messed with them dozens of times and they never stung me.

data.vi_translation: - Yes, of course. Do you know the black cripple who works for Mr. Bradish? He just started a bank. He says that whoever puts in one dollar can take out four dollars at the end of the year. So all the black folks are putting their money in there. But they don't have much anyway. Only the evening is the most. I put in more than four dollars, and I said if it doesn't work out, I'll start my own bank. Of course, that black guy doesn't want me to get involved because he says if there are two banks, there won't be enough to run the business. So he told me I could put in a handful of dollars and by the end of the year, he'd pay me back thirty-five dollars.
data.tr_translation: â€œYes. You know Old Mr. Bradishâ€™s one-legged Negro, right? Well, he started a bank and said that whoever deposits a dollar will earn an extra four dollars by the end of the year. All the Negroes deposited their money in this bank, but they didn't have much money. I was the only one who had that much money. So I wanted to get more than four dollars in interest, otherwise I said I would start my own bank. Of course, that Negro wanted to keep me out of it, because he said there wasn't enough business for two banks, so he said if you deposit five dollars in my bank, then at the end of the year you'll get thirty-five dollars.
data.es_translation: â€”Yes. Do you remember that black man of old Mr. Bradish who only has one leg? Well, he set up a bank and said that anyone who deposited a dollar would receive four more dollars at the end of the year. Well, all the black people deposited, but they didn't have much. I was the only one who had it. So I deposited more than four dollars and said that if he didn't give me what I was owed, I would open my own bank. Well, of course that black man didn't want me to compete with him, because he said there wasn't enough business for two banks, so he says I could put in my five dollars and he would pay me thirty-five at the end of the year.

data.en: This place was a tolerable long, steep hill or ridge about forty foot high. We had a rough time getting to the top, the sides was so steep and the bushes so thick. We tramped and clumb around all over it, and by-and-by found a good big cavern in the rock, most up to the top on the side towards Illinois. The cavern was as big as two or three rooms bunched together, and Jim could stand up straight in it. It was cool in there. Jim was for putting our traps in there right away, but I said we didnâ€™t want to be climbing up and down there all the time.

data.es: Aquel sitio era un cerro bastante largo y empinado, de unos cuarenta pies de alto. Nos costÃ³ trabajo llegar arriba, de empinados que eran los lados y espesos los Ã¡rboles. Anduvimos buscando por todas partes y por fin encontramos una buena caverna en la roca, casi arriba del todo, en el lado que daba a Illinois. La caverna medÃ­a tanto como dos o tres habitaciones juntas, y Jim podÃ­a estar de pie sin darse en el techo. Era fresca. Jim era partidario de guardar allÃ­ nuestras trampas inmediatamente, pero le dije que no nos convenÃ­a andar subiendo y bajando todo el tiempo.
data.vi_translation: This place is a high mound, more than ten meters high, both long and steep. We climbed to the top of the mound with quite a bit of difficulty, because the slopes on both sides were steep and the bushes were very dense. We had to take each step around the mound, and after a while, we found a large cave in the rock face, extending all the way to the top towards the Illinois shore. The cave was as wide as two or three rooms combined, and Jim could stand upright in it. This place is very cold. Jim wanted to bring our belongings here right away, but I said there was no point in climbing up and down all day.
data.tr_translation: This was quite a long and steep hill or ridge, and its height was about 12 meters. We had quite a hard time climbing the hill; the slope was very steep, and the bushes were very dense. By holding on and climbing, we explored every part of the ridge and finally found a huge cave near the top on the Illinois side. The cave was the size of two or three rooms, and Jim could stand upright inside it. It was cooler inside compared to outside. Jim immediately wanted to move the stuff there, but I said that going up and down the cave every time wouldn't be convenient for us.
data.es_translation: That place was a rather long and steep hill, about forty feet high. It was hard for us to get to the top, as the sides were steep and the trees were thick. We searched everywhere and finally found a good cave in the rock, almost at the very top, on the side facing Illinois. The cave was as big as two or three rooms together, and Jim could stand up without hitting the ceiling. It was cool. Jim was in favor of storing our traps there immediately, but I told him it wouldn't be convenient to keep going up and down all the time.

data.en: Jim said if we had the canoe hid in a good place, and had all the traps in the cavern, we could rush there if anybody was to come to the island, and they would never find us without dogs. And, besides, he said them little birds had said it was going to rain, and did I want the things to get wet?

data.es: Jim dijo que si tenÃ­amos la canoa escondida en un buen sitio y tenÃ­amos todas las trampas en la caverna, podrÃ­amos escondernos a toda prisa en ella si llegaba alguien a la isla, y que sin perros nunca nos encontrarÃ­an. data.vi_translation: Jim said that we had a boat hidden in a secret place, and the belongings were stored in this cave, so if anyone came to the island, we could escape into here. And if they didn't bring dogs, they wouldn't be able to find us. Jim also said that the young birds had predicted it was going to rain, so how could we let our belongings get all wet?
data.tr_translation: Jim said that if we hide the canoe in a good place and move all the belongings to the cave, we can immediately hide in the cave when someone comes to the island, and without the dogs, they would never find us. Moreover, the baby birds had said it was going to rain, or did I want everything to get wet?
data.es_translation: Jim said that if we had the canoe hidden in a good spot and had all the traps in the cave, we could hide in it quickly if someone came to the island, and that without dogs they would never find us. And, besides, he said that the little birds had said it was going to rain and, did I want all our things to get wet?

data.es: AsÃ­ que, en general, conseguimos un buen cargamento. Cuando estÃ¡bamos listos para marcharnos, ya nos encontrÃ¡bamos a un cuarto de milla por debajo de la isla y era pleno dÃ­a, asÃ­ que hice que Jim se tumbara en la canoa y se tapara con la colcha, porque si se sentaba la gente podÃ­a ver desde lejos que era negro. Fui remando hasta el lado de Illinois y entre tanto ganÃ© media milla a la deriva. SubÃ­ por las aguas muertas bajo la ribera y no tuve accidentes ni herÃ­ a nadie. Llegamos a casa sanos y salvos.
data.vi_translation: So we made a big haul and carried everything away. As we were about to leave the house, we realized we had drifted a quarter of a mile downstream from the island, and it was already daylight, so I told Jim to lie down in the boat and cover himself with a blanket. Because if Jim sat up, people would immediately recognize him as a runaway black man. I rowed the boat towards the Illinois shore, drifting another half mile further. When we reached calm waters, I started rowing back upstream. Nothing happened and there was no one around. We returned home safely.
data.tr_translation: Thus, overall, we had done a good job. By the time we were ready to leave the house, we had reached about a quarter mile down the island, and it was midday; so I told Jim to lie down inside the canoe and covered him with a blanket, because if he sat up, people could tell from a long distance that he was a black man. I rowed towards the Illinois shore, but while doing so, I had drifted nearly half a mile. As I came back up from the still water along the shore, nothing happened to me, nor did I see anyone. We had returned home completely safe.
data.es_translation: So, overall, we got a good load. When we were ready to leave, we were already a quarter of a mile below the island and it was broad daylight, so I had Jim lie down in the canoe and cover himself with the quilt, because if he sat up, people could see from afar that he was black. I paddled to the Illinois side and meanwhile gained half a mile drifting. I went up the still waters under the bank and had no accidents nor hurt anyone. We got home safe and sound.

Well, by night I forgot all about the snake, and when Jim flung himself down on the blanket while I struck a light the snakeâ€™s mate was there, and bit him.

data.vi_translation: Indeed, the misfortune really came. We talked about that story on the third day. Then on the sixth day, after dinner, we were lying on the grass on the hilltop, and having run out of cigarettes, I went back to the cave to get some and suddenly saw a snake lying there. I killed the snake immediately, but I coiled it up and threw it under the blanket where Jim was lying. It was just a prank, thinking that Jim would be scared when he unexpectedly saw it, and I would get a good laugh. But at night, I had forgotten about the snake, and just as Jim crawled into the blanket and I lit the lamp, the female snake, which had been there for some time, bit Jim immediately.
data.tr_translation: He really did come. It was Tuesday when we had this conversation. On Friday, while lying on the grass at the upper end of the ridge, I ran out of tobacco. When I went to the cave to get some, I encountered a rattlesnake. I killed the snake and coiled it up at the foot of Jim's blanket. I did this quite naturally, thinking we would have a laugh when Jim found it. By evening, I had forgotten about the snake, and as I was lighting the lamp, Jim threw himself onto the blanket, and the snake's mate bit him.
data.es_translation: And yes, it did arrive. It was a Tuesday when we talked about it. Well, on Friday after lunch we were lying on the grass at the top of the hill and we ran out of tobacco. I went to the cave to look for something and I came across a rattlesnake. I killed it and coiled it at the foot of Jim's blanket, very naturally, thinking how much fun it would be when Jim found it. Well, at night I forgot about the snake, and when Jim lay down on the blanket while I was lighting a lantern, there was the snake's mate and it bit him.

data.vi_translation: Jim was barefoot, and the snake had bitten him right on the heel. I realized how foolish I was for not remembering that after killing one snake and leaving it there, its mate would come and coil up beside it. Jim told me to cut off the snake's head and throw it far away, then skin it and roast a piece, saying that would neutralize the venom. He also told me to take the rings from the tails of both snakes and tie them around my wrist. Jim said that would make everything alright. Then he quietly went outside, threw the bodies of the two snakes far into the bushes; because I wasn't foolish enough to play with them.
data.tr_translation: Because he walked barefoot, a snake had bitten him on the heel. It was all because I acted like a complete fool. Wherever you leave a dead snake, its mate will come and coil up next to it. How could I have forgotten this! Jim asked me to cut off the snake's head and then skin the rest and cook a bit of it. I did as he said, he ate the snake meat and said it would help him heal. He also had me remove the snake's rattle and tie it to his wrist. This would also work. After that, I quietly went outside and threw the snake carcasses far away into the bushes; because I was determined to do everything I could so that Jim wouldn't learn it was all my fault.
data.es_translation: He was barefoot and the snake had bitten him on the heel. And all that because I had been so stupid that I didn't remember that whenever you kill a snake, its mate always appears and coils around it. Jim told me to cut off the snake's head and throw it away, then skin the body and roast a piece. That's what I did, and he ate it and said it would help cure him. He made me remove the rattles and tie them to his wrist. He said that would also relieve him. Then I went out quietly and threw the snakes far away into the bushes, because I wasn't going to let Jim find out that it was all my fault if I could help it.

data.en: Next morning I said it was getting slow and dull, and I wanted to get a stirring up some way. I said I reckoned I would slip over the river and find out what was going on. Jim liked that notion; but he said I must go in the dark and look sharp. Then he studied it over and said, couldnâ€™t I put on some of them old things and dress up like a girl? That was a good notion, too. So we shortened up one of the calico gowns, and I turned up my trouser-legs to my knees and got into it. Jim hitched it behind with the hooks, and it was a fair fit. I put on the sun-bonnet and tied it under my chin, and then for a body to look in and see my face was like looking down a joint of stove-pipe. Jim said nobody would know me, even in the daytime, hardly. I practiced around all day to get the hang of the things, and by-and-by I could do pretty well in them, only Jim said I didnâ€™t walk like a girl; and he said I must quit pulling up my gown to get at my britches-pocket. I took notice, and done better.

data.es: A la maÃ±ana siguiente dije que todo se estaba poniendo muy aburrido y que querrÃ­a ver algo de movimiento. Dije que creÃ­a que iba a cruzar el rÃ­o a ver quÃ© pasaba. A Jim le gustaba la idea; pero dijo que tenÃ­a que ir de noche y estar muy atento. DespuÃ©s lo siguiÃ³ pensando y aÃ±adiÃ³ que podrÃ­a ponerme algo de la ropa que tenÃ­amos y vestirme de niÃ±a. TambiÃ©n aquello era una buena idea. AsÃ­ que acortamos uno de los vestidos de calicÃ³ y yo me arremanguÃ© las piernas de los pantalones hasta las rodillas y me lo puse. Jim me lo abrochÃ³ por detrÃ¡s con los corchetes, y me caÃ­a bien. Me puse el bonete y me lo atÃ© bajo la barbilla, y si alguien me miraba y me veÃ­a la cara era como mirar por un tubo de chimenea. Jim dijo que nadie me conocerÃ­a, ni siquiera de dÃ­a. Estuve entrenÃ¡ndome todo el dÃ­a para acostumbrarme, y al cabo de un rato me quedaba bastante bien, sÃ³lo que Jim dijo que no andaba como las chicas, y que tenÃ­a que dejar de subirme las faldas para meterme las manos en los bolsillos. Le hice caso y me quedÃ³ mejor.
data.vi_translation: The next morning, I told Jim that I felt sad and tired, so I wanted to find some way to be a bit more active. I planned to go out to the river to see if there was anything there. Jim agreed, but told me to wait until evening to go and to be careful. He thought for a moment and then suggested that I should take off the old clothes I was wearing and disguise myself as a girl. That idea sounded good. So we took a short-cut dress, rolled up my pants to the knees, and then put the dress on. Jim used a fishhook to gather the back of the dress, making it look quite nice. I put on a wide-brimmed hat and tied the hat's string under my chin. If anyone wanted to look closely and see my face, they would have to bend down as if looking into a stove chimney. Jim said that no one would recognize me, even in broad daylight; it would be very hard to recognize me. All day long, I practiced walking to get used to it, and gradually I felt quite comfortable in that outfit; but Jim told me that my walk still didn't look like a girl's walk and that I should stop lifting the dress to put my hands in my pants pockets. I followed his advice and imitated more accurately.
data.tr_translation: The next morning, I said that life was passing slowly and boringly and that I wanted a bit of action. I thought it would be good to cross the river and see what was happening. Jim agreed with me, but he said I should go in the dark and be very careful. Then, after thinking about the matter a bit more, he asked if I could go disguised as a girl using some of those old clothes. That was indeed a good idea. So we shortened one of the calico dresses, rolled up the legs of my pants to my knees, and I put on the dress. When Jim fastened the clasps at the back of the dress, it fit me perfectly. I put on the sun hat and tied its string under my chin; since the wide brim curved down on both sides, anyone wanting to see my face would have to look in like through a stovepipe. Jim said that no one would recognize me even in daylight. I practiced all day long and gradually started to move quite comfortably in the dress; according to Jim, the only thing that didn't resemble girls was my walk; he also told me to stop lifting my skirt and plunging my hand into my pocket. It got better when I paid attention to that.
data.es_translation: The next morning I said that everything was getting very boring and that I wanted to see some action. I said that I thought I was going to cross the river to see what was happening. Jim liked the idea; but he said I had to go at night and be very careful. Then he kept thinking and added that I could put on some of the clothes we had and dress as a girl. That was also a good idea. So we shortened one of the calico dresses and I rolled up the legs of my pants to my knees and put it on. Jim fastened it at the back with the hooks, and it fit me well. I put on the bonnet and tied it under my chin, and if someone looked at me and saw my face it was like looking through a chimney pipe. Jim said no one would recognize me, not even during the day. I spent the whole day training to get used to it, and after a while it fit me quite well, only Jim said I didn't walk like girls, and that I had to stop lifting my skirts to put my hands in my pockets. I listened to him and it fit better.

data.vi_translation: - No, I'm not hungry. Earlier, I stopped at a camp two miles from here; I was hungry then, but now I'm not hungry anymore. That's why I'm walking slowly. My mother is seriously ill, we have no money and nothing left. I'm going to find and inform my uncle, Abner Moore. My mother said my uncle is at the lower end of the province over there. I've never been to this place before. Do you know my uncle?
data.tr_translation: â€œNo, no, I'm not hungry. When I got really hungry, I stopped by a farm two miles down; that's why I'm full now. That's why I was so late anyway. My mother is very sick, we ran out of money and food, so I came to talk to my uncle Abner Moore. He lives at the upper end of this town, according to my mother. I've never been here before. Do you know my uncle?â€
data.es_translation: â€”No, ma'am. I'm not hungry. I was so hungry that I had to stop two miles down from here at a farm, so I'm not hungry anymore. That's why I'm so late. My mother is sick and has run out of money and everything, and I've come to tell my uncle Abner Moore. He lives in the upper part of town, my mother told me. I've never been here before. Do you know him?

data.en: She said she wouldnâ€™t let me go by myself, but her husband would be in by-and-by, maybe in a hour and a half, and sheâ€™d send him along with me. Then she got to talking about her husband, and about her relations up the river, and her relations down the river, and about how much better off they used to was, and how they didnâ€™t know but theyâ€™d made a mistake coming to our town, instead of letting well aloneâ€”and so on and so on, till I was afeard I had made a mistake coming to her to find out what was going on in the town; but by-and-by she dropped on to pap and the murder, and then I was pretty willing to let her clatter right along. She told about me and Tom Sawyer finding the six thousand dollars (only she got it ten) and all about pap and what a hard lot he was, and what a hard lot I was, and at last she got down to where I was murdered. I says:

data.es: Dijo que no me dejarÃ­a marcharme solo pero que su marido llegarÃ­a mÃ¡s tarde, quizÃ¡ dentro de una hora y media, y le dirÃ­a que me acompaÃ±ase. DespuÃ©s se puso a hablar de su marido y de sus parientes rÃ­o arriba y de sus parientes rÃ­o abajo y de que antes vivÃ­an mucho mejor y que no sabÃ­an si no se habÃ­an equivocado al venir a nuestro pueblo, en lugar de conformarse con seguir como estaban, y asÃ­ sucesivamente, hasta que temÃ­ haberme equivocado pensando que ella me iba a dar noticias de lo que pasaba en el pueblo, pero luego se puso a hablar de padre y del asesinato y ahÃ­ sÃ­ que estaba yo dispuesto a dejar que siguiera dÃ¡ndole a la lengua. Me contÃ³ cÃ³mo Tom Sawyer y yo habÃ­amos encontrado los doce mil dÃ³lares (sÃ³lo que ella dijo que eran veinte) y toda la historia de padre, y lo malo que era y lo malo que era yo y por fin llegÃ³ a la parte en que me asesinaban, y yo dije:
data.vi_translation: She said she wouldn't let me go alone. Her husband was coming back in about an hour and a half, and she would ask him to go with me. Then she went on about her husband, and the familiar people at the river's beginning and end, about how happy things were in the old place, and how coming to this province without knowing was so long and tedious, that it would have been better to stay alone - and so on, and so on... To the point that I became scared because I had foolishly come here to ask her about things in the province. But then a moment later, she started talking about my father and the murder case. I wanted to just let her talk and listen. She talked about how Tom Sawyer and I earned twelve thousand dollars (she said twenty thousand), and everything about my father, saying my father was very stubborn, and I was very stubborn too. Then finally, she talked about the part where I was killed. I asked:
data.tr_translation: He said he wouldn't let me go alone, her husband was supposed to come in about an hour and a half and could take me. Then she started talking about her husband, she talked about their relatives upriver, she talked about their relatives downriver, they used to be very well off, but they were wondering if they made a mistake by coming to this town, they wished they had stayed in the old place â€“ and so on and so forth; I was beginning to fear that I made a mistake by coming to her to find out what was happening in the town; but then she brought up my father and the murder, and that's when I started listening to her chatter wholeheartedly. She talked about how Tom Sawyer and I found six thousand dollars (though she thought it was ten thousand), everything about my father and what a troublemaker he was, and also what a troublemaker I was; finally, she got to the part where I was killed. â€œWho did it?â€ I asked.
data.es_translation: She said she wouldn't let me leave alone but that her husband would arrive later, maybe in an hour and a half, and he would tell her to accompany me. Then she started talking about her husband and her relatives upstream and her relatives downstream and how they used to live much better and that they didn't know if they had made a mistake by coming to our town, instead of settling for staying as they were, and so on, until I feared I had been wrong in thinking that she was going to give me news about what was happening in the town, but then she started talking about father and the murder and there I was indeed willing to let her keep on talking. She told me how Tom Sawyer and I had found the twelve thousand dollars (only she said it was twenty) and the whole story about father, and how bad he was and how bad I was and finally she got to the part where I was murdered, and I said:

data.en: So I said it wouldnâ€™t be no use to try to play it any longer, and I would just make a clean breast and tell her everything, but she musnâ€™t go back on her promise. Then I told her my father and mother was dead, and the law had bound me out to a mean old farmer in the country thirty mile back from the river, and he treated me so bad I couldnâ€™t stand it no longer; he went away to be gone a couple of days, and so I took my chance and stole some of his daughterâ€™s old clothes and cleared out, and I had been three nights coming the thirty miles. I traveled nights, and hid daytimes and slept, and the bag of bread and meat I carried from home lasted me all the way, and I had a-plenty. I said I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me, and so that was why I struck out for this town of Goshen.

DespuÃ©s le dije que mi padre y mi madre habÃ­an muerto y que la ley me habÃ­a asignado a un campesino viejo y mezquino que vivÃ­a por lo menos a treinta millas del rÃ­o y que me trataba tan mal que no lo pude seguir aguantando; se habÃ­a ido un par de dÃ­as y yo aprovechÃ© la oportunidad para robar un vestido viejo de su hija y largarme, y habÃ­a tardado tres noches en recorrer las treinta millas. Viajaba de noche y me escondÃ­a a dormir de dÃ­a, y la bolsa de pan y de carne que me habÃ­a llevado me habÃ­a durado todo el camino, y todavÃ­a me quedaba.
