data.vi_translation: I thought to myself that continuing to act would be futile, so I decided to confess to her and tell her everything, but she must keep her promise. Then I told her that both my parents had died, and the law had forced me to live with an old and cruel landlord in a place thirty miles away from the river. They treated me so badly that I couldn't stay there any longer. Taking advantage of the landlord's absence for a few days, I seized the opportunity to escape and stole some clothes from his daughter, traveling for three nights straight until I arrived here. I traveled by night and hid somewhere to sleep during the day. The bundle of bread and meat I brought was just enough to eat along the way. I also said that I believed my uncle, Abner Moore, would take care of me, which is why I made my way to this Goshen area.
data.tr_translation: Then I said that there was no point in pretending anymore, I would act completely honestly and tell him everything, but he must not go back on his word. Then I told him that my father and mother had died, that they had given me to a mean old farmer thirty miles away from the river, and that he had treated me so badly that I could no longer bear it; he had gone on a trip for a few days, so I took the opportunity to steal some of his daughter's old clothes and ran away; I had been on the road for three nights and had come thirty miles; I was traveling at night, hiding and sleeping during the day; I had taken a bag full of meat and bread from the house, and my provisions would last longer. I thought my Uncle Abner Moore would take me in, so I had come to the town of Goshen.
data.es_translation: So I said that there was no point in continuing to pretend and that I would stop lying and tell him everything, but he had to keep his promise. Then I told him that my father and mother had died and that the law had assigned me to an old and mean farmer who lived at least thirty miles from the river and treated me so badly that I couldn't stand it anymore; he had gone away for a couple of days and I took the opportunity to steal an old dress from his daughter and run away, and it had taken me three nights to cover the thirty miles. I traveled at night and hid to sleep during the day, and the bag of bread and meat I had taken with me had lasted the whole way, and I still had some left. I said that I believed my uncle Abner Moore would take care of me and that was why I had come to this town of Goshen.

data.vi_translation: Jim didn't ask anything nor did he say anything, but just by looking at his hasty manner for about half an hour, one could tell he was very scared. When the raft was ready to leave the willow thicket, where we had been hiding it. The first thing we did was extinguish the fire in the cave, and after that, we didn't light any candles either.
data.tr_translation: Jim didn't ask anything, he didn't even say a word; his behavior over the next half hour was enough to show how scared he was. Now, everything we owned was on our raft, and we were ready to take it out from behind the willow curtain where we had hidden it. We had put out the fire in the cave from the very beginning and never lit even a candle outside again.
data.es_translation: Jim didn't ask any questions or say a word; but from the way he worked the next half hour, it was clear that he was terrified. By then, we had everything we owned in the raft and were ready to take it out from among the willows where it was hidden. The first thing we did was put out the fire in the cave, and after that, we didn't light even a candle.

data.en: We had mountains on the Missouri shore and heavy timber on the Illinois side, and the channel was down the Missouri shore at that place, so we warnâ€™t afraid of anybody running across us. We laid there all day, and watched the rafts and steamboats spin down the Missouri shore, and up-bound steamboats fight the big river in the middle. I told Jim all about the time I had jabbering with that woman; and Jim said she was a smart one, and if she was to start after us herself she wouldnâ€™t set down and watch a camp fireâ€”no, sir, sheâ€™d fetch a dog. Well, then, I said, why couldnâ€™t she tell her husband to fetch a dog? Jim said he bet she did think of it by the time the men was ready to start, and he believed they must a gone up-town to get a dog and so they lost all that time, or else we wouldnâ€™t be here on a tow-head sixteen or seventeen mile below the villageâ€”no, indeedy, we would be in that same old town again. So I said I didnâ€™t care what was the reason they didnâ€™t get us as long as they didnâ€™t.

data.es: VeÃ­amos montaÃ±as en el lado de Missouri y mucho bosque en el de Illionois, y el canal, por aquella parte, corrÃ­a del lado de Missouri, de forma que no tenÃ­amos miedo de encontrarnos con nadie. Nos quedamos allÃ­ todo el dÃ­a viendo las balsas y los barcos de vapor que bajaban por el lado de Missouri y los barcos de vapor que subÃ­an rÃ­o arriba peleando contra la corriente en el centro. Le contÃ© a Jim todo lo que habÃ­a pasado cuando estuve hablando con la mujer y Jim dijo que era muy lista y que si fuese ella quien nos buscara no iba a quedarse sentada vigilando una hoguera; no, seÃ±or, irÃ­a con un perro. Bueno, entonces, dije yo, Â¿por quÃ© no podÃ­a decirle a su marido que buscara un perro? Jim dijo que seguro que se le ocurrÃ­a cuando los hombres se pusieran en marcha, y que suponÃ­a que debÃ­a de haber ido a la parte de arriba del pueblo a buscar un perro, de forma que habÃ­an perdido todo aquel tiempo, o si no, no estarÃ­amos allÃ­ en la barra de arena a diecisÃ©is o diecisiete millas por debajo del pueblo; no, seÃ±or, estarÃ­amos otra vez en el pueblo. AsÃ­ que yo dije que no me importaba por quÃ© no llegaban, mientras no llegaran.
data.vi_translation: On the Illinois side, there are mountains. On the Illinois side, there are only big trees. This stretch of the river has a creek flowing towards the Illinois side, so we weren't afraid of anyone passing by here. We lay there all day, watching the rafts and steamboats going down the Illinois side, and the boats going upstream roaring in the middle of the river. I told Jim about the time I sat chatting with that woman, and Jim said she was a strange woman; if she had been the one hunting us, she wouldn't have bothered sitting by the campfire, but instead, sir, she would have led the hunt herself. I asked why she didn't suggest her husband bring the dogs. Jim said he guessed she had thought of that when her husband was about to leave, and probably the man went to town to get the dogs, which took so much time. That's why we could run to this place, sixteen or seventeen miles away from the village; otherwise, we would still be stuck in that old town. I think as long as they haven't caught us, it doesn't matter why they haven't caught us yet.
data.tr_translation: On the Missouri side, there were mountains, while on the Illinois side, there were dense forests, and since the river flowed from the Missouri side, we had no fear of encountering anyone where we were. We lay there all day watching the rafts and steamers descend towards Missouri and the steamers coming up struggle with the vast river in the middle. I told Jim about the conversation I had with that woman; he said she was a cunning woman, and if she were after us, she wouldn't just sit by the campfire â€“ no, sir, she would definitely bring a dog with her. But couldn't she have told her husband to go get a dog? Jim said that the woman had probably already thought of that before the men set out and that they were likely delayed because they went to get a dog from the upper part of the town, otherwise, we wouldn't be at this shallow spot sixteen or seventeen miles down from the village â€“ we would find ourselves back in the old town. I said that as long as they didn't catch us, I wouldn't care why they didn't catch us.
data.es_translation: We saw mountains on the Missouri side and a lot of forest on the Illinois side, and the channel, on that part, ran on the Missouri side, so we weren't afraid of running into anyone. We stayed there all day watching the rafts and steamboats going down the Missouri side and the steamboats going upriver fighting against the current in the center. I told Jim everything that had happened when I was talking to the woman and Jim said she was very smart and that if she were the one looking for us, she wouldn't just sit by a fire; no, sir, she would go with a dog. Well, then, I said, why couldn't she tell her husband to get a dog? Jim said that she would surely think of it when the men set out, and he supposed she must have gone to the upper part of the town to get a dog, so they had lost all that time, or else we wouldn't be there on the sandbar sixteen or seventeen miles below the town; no, sir, we would be back in town. So I said I didn't care why they weren't coming, as long as they didn't come.

data.en: When it was beginning to come on dark we poked our heads out of the cottonwood thicket, and looked up and down and across; nothing in sight; so Jim took up some of the top planks of the raft and built a snug wigwam to get under in blazing weather and rainy, and to keep the things dry. Jim made a floor for the wigwam, and raised it a foot or more above the level of the raft, so now the blankets and all the traps was out of reach of steamboat waves. Right in the middle of the wigwam we made a layer of dirt about five or six inches deep with a frame around it for to hold it to its place; this was to build a fire on in sloppy weather or chilly; the wigwam would keep it from being seen. We made an extra steering-oar, too, because one of the others might get broke on a snag or something. We fixed up a short forked stick to hang the old lantern on, because we must always light the lantern whenever we see a steamboat coming down-stream, to keep from getting run over; but we wouldnâ€™t have to light it for up-stream boats unless we see we was in what they call a â€œcrossingâ€; for the river was pretty high yet, very low banks being still a little under water; so up-bound boats didnâ€™t always run the channel, but hunted easy water.

data.es: Cuando empezÃ³ a oscurecer asomamos las cabezas entre los alamillos y miramos arriba y abajo y a los lados pero no vimos nada, asÃ­ que Jim sacÃ³ algunos de los troncos de arriba de la balsa y construyÃ³ un wigwam muy cÃ³modo para refugiarnos cuando hiciese mucho calor o lloviera y para tener las cosas en seco. Jim preparÃ³ un suelo para el wigwam y lo levantÃ³ un pie mÃ¡s por encima del nivel de la balsa, de forma que las mantas y las trampas estaban fuera del alcance del oleaje de los barcos de vapor. Justo en medio del wigwam pusimos una capa de polvo de cinco o seis pulgadas de grueso y la rodeamos con un bastidor para que no se saliera; era para hacer fuego cuando lloviese o hiciera frÃ­o; con el wigwam no se podrÃ­a ver. TambiÃ©n preparamos un timÃ³n de repuesto, porque uno de los que tenÃ­amos podÃ­a romperse o engancharse o lo que fuera. Preparamos un palo con una horquilla del que colgar el viejo farol, porque siempre tendrÃ­amos que encenderlo cuando viÃ©ramos un barco de vapor que venÃ­a rÃ­o abajo, para que no nos pasara inadvertido, pero no tenÃ­amos que encenderlo para los que iban rÃ­o arriba salvo que nos viÃ©ramos en lo que ellos llaman Â«entre corrientesÂ», porque el rÃ­o seguÃ­a muy alto y las riberas bajas continuaban sumergidas, de forma que los barcos que lo remontaban no subÃ­an siempre por el canal, sino que iban buscando aguas mÃ¡s fÃ¡ciles.
data.vi_translation: It started to get dark, so we poked our heads out from the pile of cotton, looked around, and saw nothing. Then Jim lifted the planks on the raft and set them up into a tent so we could crawl into it when it rained or shone, and to keep our belongings from getting wet. Jim also built an additional wooden platform about thirty centimeters high on the outside so that when large waves from passing ships hit, they wouldn't splash onto our belongings. In the middle of the tent, we made a small depression, filled it with soil about a decimeter deep, and surrounded it with wood to make a fireplace for when it rained and got cold, and also to keep it inside the tent so people wouldn't see it. We erected a short stick with a notch at the top to hang an old lantern on whenever a ship was passing downstream, to avoid collisions. As for the boats going upstream, we didn't need to light the lantern unless we were crossing the river; because the surface water flowed quite strongly, and there were many hidden sandbars below, so upstream boats often didn't travel in the middle of the river but chose spots where the current was less strong.
data.tr_translation: When it started to get dark, we poked our heads out from between the dense poplars and looked up, down, and across; there was nothing; so Jim took apart a few of the upper planks of the raft to make a narrow shelter to get under in the extreme heat and rain, and also to keep our belongings dry. He made space on the raft for the shelter, then raised it about half a meter above the raft's floor; this way, our blankets and traps would no longer be affected by the waves created by the steamers. We made a 15-centimeter deep hole in the middle of the shelter out of mud, and supported its perimeter with planks to prevent it from spreading; this was for making a fire in rainy or cool weather, and the shelter would block the fire from being seen from a distance. We also made an extra steering pole, because the others could get stuck somewhere and break. We set up a short forked stick to hang the old tattered lantern, because when you see a steamer coming down the river, you must light the lantern so it doesn't hit you; but if we weren't at one of those places they call "crossings," there was no need to light the lantern for steamers going upriver. The river was still quite high, and the low-lying banks were still underwater; so the ships going upriver could prefer places with less current instead of using the usual channel.
data.es_translation: When it started to get dark, we poked our heads out among the poplars and looked up and down and to the sides but saw nothing, so Jim took some of the logs off the top of the raft and built a very comfortable wigwam for us to take shelter in when it got very hot or rained and to keep things dry. Jim made a floor for the wigwam and raised it a foot above the level of the raft, so that the blankets and traps were out of reach of the steamboat waves. Right in the middle of the wigwam, we put a layer of dirt five or six inches thick and surrounded it with a frame to keep it from spilling out; it was for making a fire when it rained or got cold; with the wigwam, it wouldn't be visible. We also prepared a spare rudder, because one of the ones we had could break or get caught or whatever. We set up a pole with a fork to hang the old lantern from, because we would always have to light it when we saw a steamboat coming downstream, so it wouldn't miss us, but we didn't have to light it for the ones going upstream unless we found ourselves in what they call "between currents," because the river was still very high and the low banks were still submerged, so the boats going upstream didn't always go through the channel but looked for easier waters.

data.vi_translation: Jim grumbled a bit, but then he complied. He said we should stop talking, and if we must speak, to do so very quietly. Lightning flashed just as we caught sight of the wrecked ship and approached it. We searched for the mast to tie our raft to.
data.tr_translation: Jim grumbled a bit more, but finally gave in. He said we absolutely shouldn't talk unless we had to, and if we did, we should whisper. The lightning once again showed the wreck just in time, and we caught the dock on the starboard side and tied the raft.
data.es_translation: Jim grumbled a bit, but he gave in. He said we didn't have to talk more than necessary, and that in a very low voice. The lightning showed us the wrecked ship just in time again, and we grabbed the starboard davit and tied up there.

If we find their boat and let it drift away so they can't escape from this wrecked ship, one of them will be doomed. And if we find their boat, we can ensure that all of them are caught because the sheriff will come and arrest them. Now hurry up, I'll go to the side of the pilot's cabin, and you run to the other side. You go to the raft then... Oh, my God, the raft?

data.en: Well, I catched my breath and most fainted. Shut up on a wreck with such a gang as that! But it warnâ€™t no time to be sentimentering. Weâ€™d got to find that boat nowâ€”had to have it for ourselves. So we went a-quaking and shaking down the stabboard side, and slow work it was, tooâ€”seemed a week before we got to the stern. No sign of a boat. Jim said he didnâ€™t believe he could go any furtherâ€”so scared he hadnâ€™t hardly any strength left, he said. But I said, come on, if we get left on this wreck we are in a fix, sure. So on we prowled again. We struck for the stern of the texas, and found it, and then scrabbled along forwards on the skylight, hanging on from shutter to shutter, for the edge of the skylight was in the water. When we got pretty close to the cross-hall door, there was the skiff, sure enough! I could just barely see her. I felt ever so thankful. In another second I would a been aboard of her, but just then the door opened. One of the men stuck his head out only about a couple of foot from me, and I thought I was gone; but he jerked it in again, and says:

Ahora tenÃ­amos que encontrar el bote y quedarnos nosotros con Ã©l. Bajamos temblando y tiritando por el lado de estribor y tardamos mucho: pareciÃ³ que pasaba una semana antes de llegar a popa. No se veÃ­a ni seÃ±al del bote. Jim dijo que Ã©l no creÃ­a tener fuerzas para seguir: tenÃ­a tanto miedo que ya no podÃ­a mÃ¡s, dijo. Pero yo le dije: Â«Adelante, si nos quedamos aquÃ­, seguro que lo pasamos malÂ». AsÃ­ que seguimos buscando. Fuimos a la popa de la cubierta superior y lo encontramos; luego subimos como pudimos por la claraboya, agarrÃ¡ndonos a cada hierro, porque el borde de la claraboya ya estaba metido en el agua. Cuando estÃ¡bamos bastante cerca del vestÃ­bulo encontramos el bote, Â¡por fin! Yo apenas si lo vi. Me sentÃ­ muy contento. Un segundo mÃ¡s y me habrÃ­a subido a bordo, pero justo entonces se abriÃ³ la puerta. data.vi_translation: I was breathless, almost about to collapse. Being stuck on a wrecked ship with a bunch of pirates like this! But no, thereâ€™s no time to sit and lament. We had to find a way to get something out of there and escape. We walked while shaking the ship's sides, but why did it feel so slow, as if it would take a week just to reach the stern. There was no sign of any boat. Jim said he wasn't sure if he could walk anymore, he was so scared that he had no strength left to walk - that's what he said. But I urged him to keep going, if we got stuck on this wrecked ship, we would surely die. We continued to grope our way forward. We managed to reach the stern, clinging to the window frame, but the window was almost submerged. When we got to the main door to go to the passenger cabin, we saw a small boat there. It's definitely a boat, I can see it clearly. Oh my God! There is no greater joy than this. I was just about to climb up when the door suddenly opened. A person stuck their head out, just about half a meter away from me. I thought I was done for, but then the person pulled their head back in and said:
data.tr_translation: My breath got stuck in my throat, I almost fainted. Being trapped in the same wreck with such a gang! But it was no time to get emotional. We had to find that boat immediatelyâ€¦ we were going to use it ourselves. So, trembling with fear, we started to move towards the dock, progressing very slowly; it felt like it took a week to reach the stern. There was no trace of the boat. Jim said he couldn't go any further â€“ he was so scared that he had no strength left. But I explained to him that if we stayed in this wreck, we would be in big trouble. So we started walking again. We passed behind the captain's cabin, then reached for the skylight, holding onto the covers as part of the window was underwater. As we got closer to the corridor door, we finally located the boat! I could barely see its silhouette. I didn't know how to thank God. A second later, I would have jumped onto the boat, but just then the door opened. One of the men poked his head out just a few steps away from me! At that moment, I thought I was done for, but he pulled his head back in and called out:
data.es_translation: WELL, I jumped and fainted. Trapped on a shipwreck with a band of murderers! But there was no time for whining. Now we had to find the boat and take it for ourselves. We went down trembling and shivering on the starboard side and it took a long time: it seemed like a week passed before we reached the stern. There was no sign of the boat. Jim said he didn't think he had the strength to go on: he was so scared he couldn't take it anymore, he said. But I told him: "Come on, if we stay here, we're sure to have a bad time." So we kept looking. We went to the stern of the upper deck and found it; then we climbed up through the skylight as best we could, grabbing onto every iron, because the edge of the skylight was already in the water. When we were quite close to the lobby, we found the boat, at last! I barely saw it. I felt very happy. One more second and I would have boarded, but just then the door opened. One of the men stuck his head out just a couple of feet from me and I thought my final hour had come, but he pulled it back in and said:

data.en: The door slammed to because it was on the careened side; and in a half second I was in the boat, and Jim come tumbling after me. I out with my knife and cut the rope, and away we went!

data.es_translation: When we were three or four hundred yards downstream, we saw the lantern like a little spark at the door of the upper deck for a second and knew from that that the bandits had seen that they were left without the boat and were beginning to understand that they themselves had as much trouble as Jim Turner.

data.vi_translation: I threw the paddle down. Again, I heard the howling sound still behind me, but from a different place. It crept closer, it changed places, it answered itself, occasionally falling silent and then resounding in front of me; I knew that the current had already turned my boat downstream, and if it was Jim and not some other ferryman howling, I would be at ease. In the fog, nothing seen by the eyes or heard by the ears seems natural anymore.
data.tr_translation: I threw the oar into the boat. I heard the voice again, it was behind me once more but in a different place; the voice kept coming and kept changing places, and I kept responding; finally, I started hearing the voice in front of me again and realized that the current had turned the canoe's head downstream and things were falling into place, of course, if the person calling out to me was indeed Jim and not someone else. I absolutely couldn't distinguish the sounds coming through the mist; because nothing looks natural in the mist, and the sounds don't seem natural either.
data.es_translation: I put down the oar. I heard the shout again; it was still behind me, but in a different place; it sounded over and over and always changed location, and I kept responding, until finally it was ahead of me again, and I realized that the current had turned the canoe around as it moved downstream and that I was going the right way if it was Jim and not another raftsman shouting. I couldn't understand any of the voices in the fog, because in a fog nothing seems or sounds natural.

data.en: Well, I seemed to be in the open river again by-and-by, but I couldnâ€™t hear no sign of a whoop nowheres. I reckoned Jim had fetched up on a snag, maybe, and it was all up with him. I was good and tired, so I laid down in the canoe and said I wouldnâ€™t bother no more. I didnâ€™t want to go to sleep, of course; but I was so sleepy I couldnâ€™t help it; so I thought I would take jest one little cat-nap.

data.vi_translation: Then, it seems like I might have crashed into the river again, but I still haven't heard any howling sounds. I guess Jim must have crashed into some pile of wood, and maybe that's the end of it. I was so tired, I lay down in the boat and told myself not to care about it anymore. I thought maybe I should take a little nap.
data.tr_translation: It seemed that I had once again reached a freely flowing part of the river, but I couldn't hear anyone calling from around. Maybe Jim had gotten caught on a branch or something, which would mean he was done for. I was now thoroughly exhausted and felt like lying down in the canoe and letting everything take its course. Of course, I didn't want to sleep, but I was so sleepy that I couldn't help it, so I decided to take a little nap.
data.es_translation: Well, after a while it seemed like I was in open river again, but there wasn't a sound anywhere. I figured that maybe Jim had gotten caught on a log and that it was all over for him. I was extremely tired, so I lay down at the bottom of the canoe and said I wasn't going to bother anymore. Of course, I didn't want to fall asleep, but I was so sleepy that I couldn't help it, so I thought I would just take a little nap.

data.vi_translation: When we arrived, we saw Jim sitting slumped, his head tucked between his knees, sleeping, with his right hand resting on the steering oar. The oar was broken, and the surface was covered with leaves, branches, and debris. The raft had gone through a tough ordeal.
data.tr_translation: When I boarded the raft, Jim was sitting with his head between his knees, sleeping, and his right hand was resting on the steering oar. The other oar had broken off and the raft was covered all over with branches, leaves, and mud. It was clear that he had also gone through very difficult moments.
data.es_translation: When I arrived, Jim was sitting with his head between his knees, asleep, with his right arm hanging over the steering oar. The oar had broken and the raft was full of leaves, branches, and dirt. So he had had a hard time.

data.es: AsÃ­ que Jim se puso a la tarea y me lo contÃ³ todo del principio al fin, tal como habÃ­a pasado, sÃ³lo que lo adornÃ³ mucho. DespuÃ©s dijo que tenÃ­a que ponerse a Â«terpretarloÂ», porque era una advertencia. Dijo que la primera barra de arena representaba a un hombre que tratarÃ­a de hacernos algÃºn bien, pero que la corriente era otro hombre que nos querÃ­a apartar de Ã©l. Los gritos eran advertencias que nos llegarÃ­an de vez en cuando, y si no tratÃ¡bamos con todas nuestras fuerzas de comprenderlos, entonces nos darÃ­an mala suerte, en lugar de apartarnos de ella. El laberinto de barras de arena era por problemas que Ã­bamos a tener con gente de malas pulgas y todo gÃ©nero de gente mala, pero que si nos ocupÃ¡bamos de nuestros asuntos y no les respondÃ­amos ni les hacÃ­amos enfadarse, entonces saldrÃ­amos adelante y nos liberarÃ­amos de la niebla y nos meterÃ­amos en el rÃ­o grande y claro, que eran los estados libres, y ya no tendrÃ­amos mÃ¡s problemas.
data.vi_translation: So Jim began to recount everything from that moment, exactly as it had happened, and Jim also embellished it quite a bit. Then Jim said we had to figure it out this way, because it was divine retribution. He said that the first stream head was someone trying to help us, but the current was a second person wanting to cut us off from the first. The occasional howls we heard were warnings to us, and if we didn't try to understand them, we could avoid them. A bunch of other streams represented the difficulties showing that we were about to clash with troublemakers and all other bad people. But if we paid careful attention to our work, didn't tell anyone about it, and didn't complicate things, we could avoid disaster, escape the fog, reach the clear river, and that would be freedom; from there, we wouldn't encounter any more calamities.
data.tr_translation: Jim started right away and told everything as it was from beginning to end, but he embellished it quite a bit. Then he said he needed to start interpreting the dream, because the dream was a warning. The first islet was someone who would try to do us good, but the current was another man who would pull us away from him. The calls were a warning of what could happen to us at any moment, and if we didn't try hard to understand them, they would bring us bad luck instead of protecting us from it. A lot of sandbars meant we would get into trouble with quarrelsome people and all sorts of lowly individuals; but if we minded our own business and didn't respond or provoke them, we would get away and escape the fog, reaching the big clear river which was the free states. Then we would have no more troubles at all.
data.es_translation: So Jim set to the task and told me everything from beginning to end, just as it had happened, only he embellished it a lot. Then he said he had to "interpret it," because it was a warning. He said that the first sandbar represented a man who would try to do us some good, but the current was another man who wanted to keep us away from him. The shouts were warnings that would come to us from time to time, and if we didn't try with all our might to understand them, then they would bring us bad luck instead of keeping us away from it. The maze of sandbars was for problems we were going to have with ill-tempered people and all kinds of bad people, but if we minded our own business and didn't respond to them or make them angry, then we would get through and free ourselves from the fog and enter the big, clear river, which were the free states, and we would no longer have any problems.

data.en: They went off and I got aboard the raft, feeling bad and low, because I knowed very well I had done wrong, and I see it warnâ€™t no use for me to try to learn to do right; a body that donâ€™t get started right when heâ€™s little ainâ€™t got no showâ€”when the pinch comes there ainâ€™t nothing to back him up and keep him to his work, and so he gets beat. Then I thought a minute, and says to myself, hold on; sâ€™pose youâ€™d a done right and give Jim up, would you felt better than what you do now? No, says I, Iâ€™d feel badâ€”Iâ€™d feel just the same way I do now. Well, then, says I, whatâ€™s the use you learning to do right when itâ€™s troublesome to do right and ainâ€™t no trouble to do wrong, and the wages is just the same? I was stuck. I couldnâ€™t answer that. So I reckoned I wouldnâ€™t bother no more about it, but after this always do whichever come handiest at the time.

DespuÃ©s lo pensÃ© un minuto y me dije: Â«Un momento; supongamos que hubieras hecho bien y hubieras entregado a Jim, Â¿te sentirÃ­as mejor que ahora? NoÂ», me dije, Â«me sentirÃ­a mal, me sentirÃ­a igual que ahora. Bueno, entoncesÂ», me dije, Â«Â¿de quÃ© sirve aprender a hacer bien las cosas cuando tienes problemas si las haces bien y ningÃºn problema si las haces mal y el resultado es siempre el mismo?Â» Estaba atrapado. No podÃ­a responder a aquello. AsÃ­ que pensÃ© que no me seguirÃ­a preocupando del asunto, y a partir de entonces siempre hago lo que me parece mejor en cada momento.
data.vi_translation: They left, and I returned to the raft, feeling despicable and cowardly, because I knew very well that I had done something wrong. I realized that for me, even if I learned to do the right thing, it would be useless, because a person who doesn't practice doing the right thing when young won't amount to anything when grown up. Later, during difficult times, there would be no one to help or support me, and I might even be beaten. I thought for a minute, then told myself: if earlier I hadn't done the wrong thing by bringing Jim out, would I feel more at ease now? But then I said: No. If that were the case, I would feel troubled, just as I am feeling troubled now. Then I told myself: what's the point of learning to do the right thing when doing the right thing brings distress and doing the wrong thing doesn't cause any discomfort? And aren't the benefits the same either way? I felt stuck, unable to answer that question. In the end, I thought there was no point in worrying about it anymore. However, it still kept lingering in my mind afterward.
data.tr_translation: The men left, and I jumped into the skiff; I was feeling terrible because I knew very well that what I had done was wrong, and I realized that trying to learn to do the right thing was in vain; a person who hasn't been well-mannered and hasn't learned the ways when young, no matter how much they try, it's futile. When it comes down to it, they are doomed to failure because they have nothing to rely on or to help them persevere. Then I thought a little, wait a minute, I said to myself, let's say you did the right thing and turned Jim in, would you feel better than you do now? No, I said, I would feel bad â€“ just as I feel bad now. So what's the use of learning to do the right thing? Doing the right thing gets you into trouble; when you do the wrong thing, no one gets hurt, and in both cases, you feel bad. When I got to this point, I was stuck. I had no answer to give. So I decided not to worry about this matter anymore and to do whatever seemed most appropriate at the time when the moment came.
data.es_translation: They left, and I got back on the raft, feeling bad and traitorous, because I knew very well that I had done wrong, and I saw that it was useless to try to learn to do things right; when someone doesn't start off well when they are young, there's nothing to be done: when the time comes, they have nothing to lean on and support them, so they always lose. Then I thought about it for a minute and said to myself: "Wait a minute; suppose you had done right and turned Jim in, would you feel better than now? No," I said to myself, "I would feel bad, I would feel just as I do now. Well, then," I said to myself, "what's the use of learning to do things right when you have problems if you do them right and no problems if you do them wrong and the result is always the same?" I was trapped. I couldn't answer that. So I thought I wouldn't worry about it anymore, and from then on, I always do what seems best to me at the moment.

data.en: Then we talked about the money. It was a pretty good raiseâ€”twenty dollars apiece. Jim said we could take deck passage on a steamboat now, and the money would last us as far as we wanted to go in the free States. He said twenty mile more warnâ€™t far for the raft to go, but he wished we was already there.

data.tr_translation: Then we talked about the money issue. We had twenty dollars each. Jim said we could now buy a ticket on a steamboat, and it would be more than enough for both of us until we reached the free states. Going another twenty miles by raft wasn't much, but Jim wanted to be there as soon as possible.
data.es_translation: Then we talked about the money. It wasn't bad at all: twenty dollars each. Jim said that now we could take deck passage on a steamboat and the money would last us as far as we wanted to go in the free states. He said that twenty more miles wasn't much distance for the raft, but he wished we had already arrived.

However, I had forgotten that. We spent the daylight hours on a small island that could be considered close to the left shore. A possibility started to come to my mind. Jim was also getting suspicious. â€œMaybe we passed Cairo on that foggy night,â€ I said.

We stayed the whole day on a grassy islet quite close to the left shore. I began to suspect something. Jim did too. I said:

data.en: We could hear her pounding along, but we didnâ€™t see her good till she was close. She aimed right for us. Often they do that and try to see how close they can come without touching; sometimes the wheel bites off a sweep, and then the pilot sticks his head out and laughs, and thinks heâ€™s mighty smart. Well, here she comes, and we said she was going to try and shave us; but she didnâ€™t seem to be sheering off a bit. She was a big one, and she was coming in a hurry, too, looking like a black cloud with rows of glow-worms around it; but all of a sudden she bulged out, big and scary, with a long row of wide-open furnace doors shining like red-hot teeth, and her monstrous bows and guards hanging right over us. There was a yell at us, and a jingling of bells to stop the engines, a powwow of cussing, and whistling of steamâ€”and as Jim went overboard on one side and I on the other, she come smashing straight through the raft.

data.es: PodÃ­amos oÃ­r su motor, pero no lo vimos bien hasta que se acercÃ³. VenÃ­a directo hacia nosotros. Muchas veces hacen eso y tratan de ver hasta dÃ³nde pueden acercarse sin tocarlo a uno; a veces la rueda arranca un tablÃ³n, y entonces el piloto asoma la cabeza y se echa a reÃ­r y se cree muy listo. Bueno, aquÃ­ viene, y decidimos que iba a tratar de afeitarnos, pero no parecÃ­a desviarse ni un poco. Era grande y venÃ­a a toda velocidad, como una nube negra con filas de luciÃ©rnagas a los lados; pero de pronto se vio entero, enorme que daba miedo, con una fila larga de portezuelas de hornos abiertas y brillantes como dientes al rojo y con los costados y las barandillas monstruosos justo encima de nosotros. Alguien nos gritÃ³, y se oyÃ³ un ruido de campanas para frenar las mÃ¡quinas, un montÃ³n de juramentos y el silbido del vapor, y justo cuando Jim saltaba de un lado y yo del otro, arremetiÃ³ contra la balsa y la hizo aÃ±icos.
data.vi_translation: We could clearly hear the clattering sound but couldn't see the ship clearly until it got closer. The ship seemed to be heading straight towards us. They usually do this to see how close they can get without slowing down. Sometimes their paddle wheel breaks someone's oar, and then the helmsman sticks his head out and laughs, thinking it's quite amusing. As the ship approached, we thought it might hit us, and it didn't seem to be veering away at all. The ship was very large and moving quickly, looking like a big dark cloud bristling with paddle wheels and surrounded by fireflies. But then suddenly it swerved, looming menacingly, with a row of lit windows resembling a large set of red teeth, and its paddles and oars seemed ready to crash down on us. There were shouts, then a bell rang to slow the engine, followed by curses, the sound of the engine screeching, and just as Jim jumped to one side and I jumped to the other, the ship's paddle wheel smashed our raft to pieces.
data.tr_translation: We could hear the sound of the ship, but we didn't see it until it got really close. It was coming straight at us. They often do this and want to show how close they can pass without hitting; sometimes they hit the edge of the boat and the helmsman sticks his head out and laughs; he thinks he's very clever. Here it was coming, we thought it would just graze us, but it seemed like it wouldn't change its course even a little. It was a big steamer, coming fast; it looked like a huge cloud surrounded by fireflies; then suddenly it was upon us, with its wide-open furnace mouths glowing like red-hot teeth, its massive prow and stanchions above our heads, it was enormous and terrifying. I heard someone shouting at us, bells rang to stop the engine, I heard the hiss of steam; but it was too late, as Jim jumped to one side and I to the other in a desperate attempt to escape, the ship struck the boat right in the middle.
data.es_translation: We could hear its engine, but we didn't see it clearly until it got closer. It was coming straight towards us. Many times they do that and try to see how close they can get without touching you; sometimes the wheel rips off a plank, and then the pilot sticks his head out and laughs, thinking he's very clever. Well, here it comes, and we decided it was going to try to shave us, but it didn't seem to veer off even a little. It was big and coming at full speed, like a black cloud with rows of fireflies on the sides; but suddenly it came fully into view, enormous and frightening, with a long row of open furnace doors glowing like red-hot teeth and with monstrous sides and railings right above us. Someone shouted at us, and there was a sound of bells to stop the engines, a bunch of curses and the hiss of steam, and just as Jim jumped to one side and I to the other, it crashed into the raft and smashed it to pieces.

data.vi_translation: Then it was Charlotte's turn. She was twenty-five years old, tall, and proud; whenever she wasn't losing her temper, she tried to be kind. But when she did lose her temper, she could make you tremble in your boots, just like her father. She was quite beautiful.
data.tr_translation: Then came Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five years old, tall, proud, and magnificent, but extremely kind when not provoked; when she was angry, just like her father, she would give such a look that it would make your knees buckle. She was a beautiful girl.
data.es_translation: Then came Miss Charlotte; she was twenty-five years old and was tall, proud, and stunning, but very kind when she wasn't angry; although when she was, she would give looks that left one frozen, just like her father. She was very beautiful.

data.vi_translation: Each person in the house had their own black servant. Even young Buck had one. The black servant they assigned to me had plenty of free time, because I never wanted anyone to do anything for me. But young Buck was always ordering people around, yelling all the time.
data.tr_translation: Everyone had a black servant who took care of them â€“ Buck had one too. My black servant had it easy, really, because I wasn't used to having someone else do things for me, whereas Buck's black servant was working hard.

data.vi_translation: Buck said - This is how it is, a plantation is like this: One person has a conflict with another person, then kills them. Then the siblings of the person who was killed take revenge. Then the siblings of this person kill the other person. Both sides keep killing each other like that endlessly. Eventually, even their relatives get involved, and gradually everyone gets killed, so there is no more plantation. But that is a long story.
data.tr_translation: â€œAlright,â€ said Buck, â€œa blood feud is something like this: A man fights with another man, kills him in the fight; then the dead man's brother comes and kills him; then the brothers from both sides start killing each other; then the cousins get involved â€“ in the end, everyone dies and the blood feud ends like that. But it is a slow thing; it takes a very long time.â€
data.es_translation: â€”Well â€”said Buckâ€”, a blood feud is something like this: a man fights with another and kills him, then the brother of the other man kills him; after that, the other brothers from each family start looking for each other, then the cousins get involved and after a while everyone is dead and the blood feud is over. But it's very slow and takes a lot of time.

data.en: By-and-by the men stopped cavorting around and yelling. They started riding towards the store; then up gets one of the boys, draws a steady bead over the wood-rank, and drops one of them out of his saddle. All the men jumped off of their horses and grabbed the hurt one and started to carry him to the store; and that minute the two boys started on the run. They got half way to the tree I was in before the men noticed. Then the men see them, and jumped on their horses and took out after them. They gained on the boys, but it didnâ€™t do no good, the boys had too good a start; they got to the woodpile that was in front of my tree, and slipped in behind it, and so they had the bulge on the men again. One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slim young chap about nineteen years old.

data.vi_translation: After a while, they stopped running around and shouting. They headed towards the warehouse. Immediately, a boy stood up and fired a shot from the pile of wood, hitting one of the group who fell off his horse. They quickly jumped off their horses to pick up the injured person and take him back to the warehouse, just as the other two boys started to run away. The two boys had run halfway from there to where I was hiding when suddenly the others saw them and immediately mounted their horses to give chase. They almost caught up, but it was no use; the two boys ran very fast and quickly slipped into the pile of wood right in front of the tree where I was hiding. That gave them an advantage over the others. One of the two boys was Buck, while the other was a skinny boy about nineteen years old.
data.tr_translation: After a while, the men stopped shouting and yelling around. They rode their horses towards the warehouse; at that moment, one of the boys stood up, took aim from the top of the woodpile, and shot one of the riders. The men immediately dismounted and dragged the wounded one by the arm towards the warehouse; just then, two boys started to run away. The boys did not attract attention until they were halfway to the tree I was sitting on. Then the men saw them, jumped on their horses, and chased after them. The men were coming fast, but they still couldn't catch up, because the boys were too far away; they reached the woodpile in front of my tree and took cover behind it again. One of the boys was Buck, and the other was a slender young man around nineteen years old.
data.es_translation: A while passed and the men stopped circling and shouting. They started running towards the warehouse, and then one of the boys aimed steadily over the wood and knocked one of them off his horse. All the men dismounted from their horses, grabbed the injured man, and began carrying him towards the warehouse, and at that moment the two boys started running. They were halfway to the tree where I was before the men noticed. Then they saw them and jumped on their horses and raced after them. They were gaining ground on the boys, but it didn't help because the boys had a good lead; they reached the pile of wood in front of my tree and hid behind it, so they were protected from the men again. One of the boys was Buck and the other was a thin boy about nineteen years old.

data.en: When I got down out of the tree, I crept along down the river bank a piece, and found the two bodies laying in the edge of the water, and tugged at them till I got them ashore; then I covered up their faces, and got away as quick as I could. I cried a little when I was covering up Buckâ€™s face, for he was mighty good to me.

data.es: Cuando me bajÃ© del Ã¡rbol, me deslicÃ© un rato por la orilla, encontrÃ© los dos cadÃ¡veres al borde del agua y tirÃ© de ellos hasta dejarlos en seco; despuÃ©s les tapÃ© la cara y me marchÃ© a toda la velocidad que pude. LlorÃ© un poco mientras tapaba a Buck, porque se habÃ­a portado muy bien conmigo.
data.vi_translation: After climbing down from the tree, I crawled along the riverbank for a while and saw two bodies lying on the water's edge. I mustered all my strength to pull the two bodies further inland and turned them over to see their faces, then I ran away as fast as I could. When I saw Buck's face, I cried for a long time because he was so kind to me.
data.tr_translation: After climbing down from the tree, I carefully and quietly advanced along the riverbank and found two bodies floating very close to the shore. I pulled them to the land, covered their faces with something, and left as quickly as possible. While covering Buck's face, I shed a few tears because he had treated me very well.
data.es_translation: When I got down from the tree, I slid along the shore for a while, found the two corpses at the water's edge, and dragged them until they were on dry land; then I covered their faces and left as quickly as I could. I cried a little while covering Buck, because he had treated me very well.

data.en: I never felt easy till the raft was two mile below there and out in the middle of the Mississippi. Then we hung up our signal lantern, and judged that we was free and safe once more. I hadnâ€™t had a bite to eat since yesterday, so Jim he got out some corn-dodgers and buttermilk, and pork and cabbage and greensâ€”there ainâ€™t nothing in the world so good when itâ€™s cooked rightâ€”and whilst I eat my supper we talked, and had a good time. I was powerful glad to get away from the feuds, and so was Jim to get away from the swamp. We said there warnâ€™t no home like a raft, after all. Other places do seem so cramped up and smothery, but a raft donâ€™t. You feel mighty free and easy and comfortable on a raft.

data.es: No me quedÃ© tranquilo hasta que la balsa bajÃ³ dos millas por el centro del Mississippi. DespuÃ©s colgamos nuestro farol de seÃ±ales y calculamos que ya volvÃ­amos a estar libres y a salvo. Yo no habÃ­a comido nada desde ayer, asÃ­ que Jim sacÃ³ unos bollos de maÃ­z y leche con nata, y carne de cerdo con col y berzas (no hay nada mejor en el mundo cuando estÃ¡ bien guisado) y mientras yo cenaba charlamos y pasamos un buen rato. Yo me alegraba mucho de alejarme de las venganzas de sangre, y Jim del pantano. Dijimos que no habÃ­a casa como una balsa, despuÃ©s de todo. Otros sitios pueden parecer abarrotados y sofocantes, pero una balsa no. En una balsa se siente uno muy libre y tranquilo.
data.vi_translation: Until our raft had gone upstream for a few miles downstream and reached the middle of the Mississippi River, we were not at ease. Then we hung up the signal light, thinking that once again we had escaped danger and were free. Since yesterday, I hadn't had anything to eat. Jim took out some fried bread; milk cakes, and there was even meat and green vegetables. There is nothing more delicious in the world than eating something hot like this. I ate and chatted with Jim very happily. I was glad to have escaped the plantation; and Jim was also glad to have escaped the swamp. We told each other that ultimately, nowhere was better than our raft. Other places are cramped and suffocating. But on the raft, it's not like that. On the raft, you feel completely free, comfortable, and secure.
data.tr_translation: I couldn't feel at ease until we were two miles down and reached the middle of the Mississippi. Then we lit the signal lantern and had no doubt that we were once again free and safe. I hadn't put a single bite in my mouth since yesterday; Jim soon brought out cornbread, skimmed milk, pork sausage, cabbage, and greens â€“ when prepared by an expert, no meal could match its taste. We chatted while I ate and had a great time. I was very happy to have escaped the blood feuds, and Jim was glad to have gotten out of the swamp. There was nothing like having your own raft. Everywhere else felt cramped and suffocating, but not the raft. On the raft, one feels completely free; carefree and comfortable.
data.es_translation: I didn't feel at ease until the raft had drifted two miles down the center of the Mississippi. Then we hung our signal lantern and figured we were free and safe again. I hadn't eaten anything since yesterday, so Jim brought out some corn muffins and milk with cream, and pork with cabbage and greens (there's nothing better in the world when it's well-cooked) and while I had dinner, we chatted and had a good time. I was very glad to get away from the blood feuds, and Jim from the swamp. We said there was no home like a raft, after all. Other places may seem crowded and stifling, but not a raft. On a raft, one feels very free and at ease.

data.en: A little smoke couldnâ€™t be noticed now, so we would take some fish off of the lines and cook up a hot breakfast. And afterwards we would watch the lonesomeness of the river, and kind of lazy along, and by-and-by lazy off to sleep. Wake up by-and-by, and look to see what done it, and maybe see a steamboat coughing along up-stream, so far off towards the other side you couldnâ€™t tell nothing about her only whether she was a stern-wheel or side-wheel; then for about an hour there wouldnâ€™t be nothing to hear nor nothing to seeâ€”just solid lonesomeness. Next youâ€™d see a raft sliding by, away off yonder, and maybe a galoot on it chopping, because theyâ€™re most always doing it on a raft; youâ€™d see the axe flash and come downâ€”you donâ€™t hear nothing; you see that axe go up again, and by the time itâ€™s above the manâ€™s head then you hear the kâ€™chunk!â€”it had took all that time to come over the water. So we would put in the day, lazying around, listening to the stillness. Once there was a thick fog, and the rafts and things that went by was beating tin pans so the steamboats wouldnâ€™t run over them. A scow or a raft went by so close we could hear them talking and cussing and laughingâ€”heard them plain; but we couldnâ€™t see no sign of them; it made you feel crawly; it was like spirits carrying on that way in the air. Jim said he believed it was spirits; but I says:

data.es: A esa hora no importaba hacer un poco de humo por que no se veÃ­a, asÃ­ que sacÃ¡bamos los peces de los sedales y nos preparÃ¡bamos un desayuno caliente. Y despuÃ©s contemplÃ¡bamos la soledad del rÃ­o y hacÃ­amos el vago, y poco a poco nos Ã­bamos quedando dormidos. Nos despertÃ¡bamos, y cuando mirÃ¡bamos para averiguar por quÃ©, a veces veÃ­amos un barco de vapor que venÃ­a jadeando rÃ­o arriba, a tanta distancia al otro lado que lo Ãºnico que se podÃ­a ver de Ã©l era si llevaba la rueda a popa o a los costados; despuÃ©s, durante una hora no habÃ­a nada que oÃ­r ni que ver: sÃ³lo la soledad. Luego se veÃ­a una balsa que se deslizaba a lo lejos, y a veces uno de los tipos de a bordo cortando leÃ±a, porque es lo que hacen casi siempre en las balsas y se ve cÃ³mo el hacha brilla y baja, pero no se oye nada; se ve que el hacha vuelve a subir y cuando ya ha llegado por encima de la cabeza del hombre entonces se oye el hachazo, que ha tardado todo ese rato en cruzar el agua. Y asÃ­ pasÃ¡bamos el dÃ­a, haciendo el vago, escuchando el silencio. Una vez bajÃ³ una niebla densa y las balsas y todo lo que pasaba hacÃ­an ruido con sartenes para que los buques de vapor no las pasaran por alto. Una chalana o una balsa pasaban tan cerca que oÃ­amos lo que decÃ­a la gente de a bordo, sus maldiciones y sus risas, los oÃ­amos perfectamente, pero no veÃ­amos ni seÃ±al de ellos; era una sensaciÃ³n muy rara, como si fuesen espÃ­ritus hablando en el aire. Jim dijo que creÃ­a que lo eran, pero yo dije:
data.vi_translation: At this moment, even if a little smoke rises, no one can see it. We lifted a few fish at the end of the line to make a hot meal. Then we sat back down to watch the deserted river. People started to get tired, and we lay down to sleep. From time to time, we woke up and looked outside to see if there was anything. Perhaps it was a boat laboriously climbing upstream on the far side of the river; from a distance, it was impossible to tell if it was a stern-wheeler or had paddle wheels on both sides. Then another hour passed, with nothing to see or hear, just silence. Later, a raft drifted by on the outer edge. Perhaps there was a guy on the raft chopping wood, because they often chop wood right on the raft. From inside here, they could see the glint of the axe being raised, and just as the axe was lifted above his head, there was a thud, a sound that took a moment to travel over the water before reaching our ears. Then we lay back down, listening to the quiet return. Once, in thick fog, boats and rafts had to clang pots and pans to avoid being hit by steamships. A ferry or raft or something passed by us, so close that we could clearly hear them talking, swearing, and laughing loudly, even though we couldn't see anything, as if we were blindfolded; it really felt like ghostly voices drifting through the air. Jim said maybe they really were ghosts. I said:
data.tr_translation: We were preparing a warm breakfast with some of the fish caught on the lines, thinking a little smoke wouldn't attract attention anymore. Then we would watch the solitude of the river for a while; laze around; gradually get drowsy and eventually fall asleep. Then we would wake up to a noise and see a steamboat coughing its way upriver, but it would be on the other side of the river and so far away that it was impossible to tell whether its paddle wheel was on the side or the stern. Then for about an hour, nothing else would be heard or seen â€“ just solitude. Then you would see a raft passing in the distance, perhaps with an inexperienced raftsman cutting wood on it, because such types always cut wood on the raft; you would see the axe glint as it rises and falls â€“ but you wouldn't hear anything; then the axe rises again; as it reaches above the man's head, you hear the thud! sound, it takes that long for the sound to reach you over the water. That's how we spent the day, lazing around, listening intently to the silence. Once, a thick fog descended, and people on rafts and barges were clanging pots and pans to avoid being hit by steamboats as they moved along. A barge or raft passed so close to us that we could hear the people inside cursing and laughing â€“ we could clearly understand what they were saying; but we couldn't see them for even a moment; this sent chills down our spines, as if we were listening to the voices of spirits gliding through the air. Jim even said he believed they were spirits.
data.es_translation: At that hour, it didn't matter to make a little smoke because it couldn't be seen, so we took the fish off the lines and prepared a hot breakfast. And then we would contemplate the solitude of the river and laze around, and little by little we would fall asleep. We would wake up, and when we looked to find out why, sometimes we saw a steamboat puffing upriver, so far on the other side that the only thing you could see was whether it had the wheel at the stern or on the sides; then, for an hour there was nothing to hear or see: only solitude. Then we would see a raft gliding in the distance, and sometimes one of the guys on board chopping wood, because that's what they almost always do on rafts, and you could see the axe shining and coming down, but you couldn't hear anything; you would see the axe rise again, and when it was above the man's head, then you would hear the chop, which had taken all that time to cross the water. And so we spent the day, lazing around, listening to the silence. Once a dense fog came down, and the rafts and everything that passed by made noise with pans so that the steamboats wouldn't overlook them. A skiff or a raft would pass so close that we could hear what the people on board were saying, their curses and their laughter, we could hear them perfectly, but we couldn't see any sign of them; it was a very strange feeling, as if they were spirits talking in the air. Jim said he thought they were, but I said:

data.en: Sometimes weâ€™d have that whole river all to ourselves for the longest time. Yonder was the banks and the islands, across the water; and maybe a sparkâ€”which was a candle in a cabin window; and sometimes on the water you could see a spark or twoâ€”on a raft or a scow, you know; and maybe you could hear a fiddle or a song coming over from one of them crafts. Itâ€™s lovely to live on a raft. We had the sky up there, all speckled with stars, and we used to lay on our backs and look up at them, and discuss about whether they was made or only just happened. Jim he allowed they was made, but I allowed they happened; I judged it would have took too long to make so many. Jim said the moon could a laid them; well, that looked kind of reasonable, so I didnâ€™t say nothing against it, because Iâ€™ve seen a frog lay most as many, so of course it could be done. We used to watch the stars that fell, too, and see them streak down. Jim allowed theyâ€™d got spoiled and was hove out of the nest.

data.es: A veces tenÃ­amos el rÃ­o entero para nosotros solos durante ratos larguÃ­simos. A lo lejos se veÃ­an las riberas y las islas, al otro lado del agua, y a veces una chispa que era una vela en la ventana de una cabaÃ±a, y a veces en medio del agua se veÃ­a una chispa o dos: ya se sabe, una balsa o una chalana, y se podÃ­a oÃ­r un violÃ­n o una canciÃ³n que llegaba de una de aquellas embarcaciones. Es maravilloso vivir en una balsa. Arriba tenÃ­amos el cielo, todo manchado de estrellas, y nos echÃ¡bamos de espaldas, las mirÃ¡bamos y discutÃ­amos si alguien las habÃ­a hecho o habÃ­an salido porque sÃ­. Jim siempre decÃ­a que las habÃ­an hecho, pero yo sostenÃ­a que habÃ­an salido; rne parecÃ­a que llevarÃ­a demasiado tiempo hacer tantas. Jim dijo que la luna podrÃ­a haberlas puesto; bueno, aquello parecÃ­a bastante razonable, asÃ­ que no dije nada en contra, porque he visto ranas poner casi tantos huevos, asÃ­ que desde luego era posible. TambiÃ©n mirÃ¡bamos las estrellas que caÃ­an y veÃ­amos la estela que dejaban. Jim decÃ­a que era porque se habÃ­an portado mal y las habÃ­an echado del nido.
data.vi_translation: Sometimes it feels like this whole river belongs to us. Looking across the water, far away on the other side is the riverbank, and the island, and perhaps there is a light, a candle flame in the window frame. Sometimes there are also a few lights on the water's surface. Those are the lights on the rafts or ferries, and perhaps we can even hear the sound of a violin or singing echoing out. Living on a raft or a float, how interesting it is. Above us, there is only the high sky, dotted with stars, and we often lie on our backs looking up at the sky, debating with each other about who made those stars, and I just say they exist on their own. I said if someone made that many stars, it would surely take a lot of time. Jim said the moon gave birth to those stars. Well, it makes sense, so I couldn't say anything to refute that theory. And since I've seen frogs lay a lot of eggs, it could be that the moon gave birth to those stars. We also often look at shooting stars, watching their trails stretch down to the horizon. Jim said those are the bad stars, flying away from their nest.
data.tr_translation: Sometimes there would be no one else on the river for a very long time except us. We would see the shores and islands ahead; maybe a spark â€“ a candle seen from a cabin window â€“ would catch our eye; sometimes we would see one or two sparks on the water â€“ on a raft or a barge; sometimes we would hear the sound of a violin or someone singing from one of the river vessels. Living on the raft was very beautiful. The sky above would be speckled with stars, and we would lie on our backs and watch the stars, debating whether they were made or if they appeared suddenly â€“ according to Jim, they were made, but I thought they appeared suddenly; in my opinion, there were too many of them to be made one by one. Jim had said that the moon might have laid them; well, since this seemed reasonable, I didn't object, because I had seen a frog with as many offspring as there were stars, so this was something that could happen. We would also see shooting stars and watch them descend. According to Jim, these were the rotten ones and that's why they were picked out and fell from the nest.
data.es_translation: Sometimes we had the whole river to ourselves for very long stretches. In the distance, we could see the banks and the islands on the other side of the water, and sometimes a spark that was a light in the window of a cabin, and sometimes in the middle of the water, we saw a spark or two: you know, a raft or a skiff, and you could hear a violin or a song coming from one of those boats. It's wonderful to live on a raft. Above us, we had the sky, all speckled with stars, and we would lie on our backs, look at them, and discuss whether someone had made them or if they had just appeared on their own. Jim always said that they had been made, but I maintained that they had just appeared; it seemed to me it would take too long to make so many. Jim said that the moon might have put them there; well, that seemed quite reasonable, so I didn't say anything against it, because I've seen frogs lay almost as many eggs, so it was certainly possible. We also watched the falling stars and saw the trail they left behind. Jim said it was because they had misbehaved and had been thrown out of the nest.

data.en: One morning about daybreak I found a canoe and crossed over a chute to the main shoreâ€”it was only two hundred yardsâ€”and paddled about a mile up a crick amongst the cypress woods, to see if I couldnâ€™t get some berries. Just as I was passing a place where a kind of a cowpath crossed the crick, here comes a couple of men tearing up the path as tight as they could foot it. I thought I was a goner, for whenever anybody was after anybody I judged it was meâ€”or maybe Jim. I was about to dig out from there in a hurry, but they was pretty close to me then, and sung out and begged me to save their livesâ€”said they hadnâ€™t been doing nothing, and was being chased for itâ€”said there was men and dogs a-coming. They wanted to jump right in, but I says:

data.es: Una maÃ±ana, hacia el amanecer, vi una canoa y yo crucÃ© por un canal a la costa principal (no habÃ­a mÃ¡s que doscientas yardas) y remÃ© una milla hacia un arroyo entre los cipreses, para ver si conseguÃ­a unas moras. Justo cuando estaba pasando por un sitio donde una especie de senda de vacas cruzaba el arroyo apareciÃ³ un par de hombres corriendo a toda la velocidad que podÃ­an. PensÃ© que me habÃ­a llegado la hora, pues siempre que alguien buscaba a alguien me parecÃ­a que era a mÃ­, o quizÃ¡ a Jim. Estaba a punto de marcharme a toda prisa, pero ya estaban muy cerca de mÃ­, y gritaron y me pidieron que les salvara la vida: dijeron que no habÃ­an hecho nada y que por eso los perseguÃ­an, que venÃ­an hombres con perros. QuerÃ­an meterse directamente en mi canoa, pero les dije:
data.vi_translation: One morning, just as the sun was rising, I found a boat, rowed through a swift current to reach the main shore, only a few hundred yards away. Then I rowed about half a mile further to a spot with bushes near a pine forest to see if I could find any berries. As I reached a narrow path just wide enough for cattle to pass through, suddenly two people came running out from that small path. I thought to myself, this is trouble, because if anyone is looking for someone here, it could only be me or Jim. I was about to slip away when those people ran up close, calling me and begging me to save them. They said they hadn't done anything wrong, yet people were chasing them. Then they said that people with dogs were about to catch up to them. They wanted to jump right into my boat, but I said:
data.tr_translation: One morning, just as dawn was breaking, I found a canoe and entered a swift current â€“ it was only about two hundred meters â€“ and reached the riverbank. Then, I went up a creek among the cypress trees for about a mile to find some berries. Just as I was passing a place where the creek cut across a wide path, didn't two men come running for their lives! Ah, this time I'm done for, I said to myself; because whenever I saw someone running, I thought they were chasing me â€“ or Jim. I was about to grab the oars to get away quickly, but they were already very close, calling out to me and asking me to save their lives â€“ according to them, they hadn't done anything and were being chased for no reason â€“ there were men and dogs behind them. They immediately wanted to jump into the canoe, but I stopped them:
data.es_translation: One morning, around dawn, I saw a canoe and I crossed a channel to the main shore (it was no more than two hundred yards) and rowed a mile towards a stream among the cypresses, to see if I could get some blackberries. Just as I was passing a spot where a sort of cow path crossed the stream, a pair of men appeared running as fast as they could. I thought my time had come, because whenever someone was looking for someone, it seemed to me that it was for me, or maybe for Jim. I was about to leave in a hurry, but they were already very close to me, and they shouted and asked me to save their lives: they said they hadn't done anything and that's why they were being chased, that men with dogs were coming. They wanted to get directly into my canoe, but I told them:

Yes, gentlemen; before you stands the legitimate King of France, wandering in misery, exiled, trampled underfoot, wearing blue jeans.â€

data.en: The duke done it, and Jim and me was pretty glad to see it. It took away all the uncomfortableness and we felt mighty good over it, because it would a been a miserable business to have any unfriendliness on the raft; for what you want, above all things, on a raft, is for everybody to be satisfied, and feel right and kind towards the others.

data.es: El duque se la dio, y Jim y yo nos alegramos mucho de ver aquello. AsÃ­ que dejamos de sentirnos molestos y nos alegramos mucho porque habrÃ­a sido una pena no llevarse bien en la balsa; porque lo primero que hace falta en una balsa es que todo el mundo estÃ© contento, que se sienta bien y se lleve bien con los demÃ¡s.
data.vi_translation: The Duke reached out his hand to shake. Jim and I were glad to see that. The heavy atmosphere suddenly dissipated, and we felt happy as well. On a raft, everyone must be cheerful and harmonious with each other for life to be bearable for a few moments.
data.tr_translation: When the Duke did what he said, Jim and I were very happy. All our discomforts flew away, we felt very good, because there is nothing as terrible as resentment on a raft; the first thing you want on a raft is for everyone to be satisfied, to treat others correctly and well.
data.es_translation: The duke gave it to her, and Jim and I were very glad to see that. So we stopped feeling annoyed and were very happy because it would have been a shame not to get along on the raft; because the first thing you need on a raft is for everyone to be happy, to feel good, and to get along with each other.

data.en: It didnâ€™t take me long to make up my mind that these liars warnâ€™t no kings nor dukes at all, but just low-down humbugs and frauds. But I never said nothing, never let on; kept it to myself; itâ€™s the best way; then you donâ€™t have no quarrels, and donâ€™t get into no trouble. If they wanted us to call them kings and dukes, I hadnâ€™t no objections, â€™long as it would keep peace in the family; and it warnâ€™t no use to tell Jim, so I didnâ€™t tell him. If I never learnt nothing else out of pap, I learnt that the best way to get along with his kind of people is to let them have their own way.

data.es: No me hizo falta mucho tiempo para comprender que aquellos mentirosos no eran reyes ni duques en absoluto, sino estafadores y farsantes de lo mÃ¡s bajo. Pero nunca dije nada ni lo revelÃ©; me lo guardÃ© para mis adentros; es lo mejor; asÃ­ no hay peleas y no se mete uno en lÃ­os. Si querÃ­an que los llamÃ¡ramos reyes y duques, yo no tenÃ­a nada que objetar, siempre que hubiera paz en la familia, y no valÃ­a de nada decÃ­rselo a Jim, asÃ­ que no lo hice. Si algo aprendÃ­ de padre es que la mejor forma de llevarse bien con gente asÃ­ es dejarla que vaya a su aire.
data.vi_translation: Before long, I realized that these two guys were not kings or dukes at all but just swindlers and thieves. But I didn't say a word or show any attitude. That was the best way to avoid troublesome arguments. If they wanted to be called kings or dukes, I would call them that as long as it kept the peace. I didn't tell Jim either because it wouldn't do any good. If I hadn't learned anything else from my father, I learned one thing here: just live with people like this and let them do whatever they want.
data.tr_translation: It didn't take me long to realize that these two liars were not a king or a duke, but mere braggarts and frauds. But I definitely didn't open my mouth, I didn't reveal that I understood; that was the best, then you don't have to argue, and you don't get into trouble. If they wanted us to call them king and duke, I wouldn't object as long as we could maintain peace in the family; besides, it wouldn't have been useful to explain this to Jim, so I didn't. If I learned nothing else from my father, I learned that the only way to get along with people like him was not to mess with them.
data.es_translation: It didn't take me long to realize that those liars were not kings or dukes at all, but the lowest of swindlers and frauds. But I never said anything or revealed it; I kept it to myself; it's the best way; that way there are no fights and you don't get into trouble. If they wanted us to call them kings and dukes, I had no objection, as long as there was peace in the family, and it was no use telling Jim, so I didn't. If I learned anything from my father, it's that the best way to get along with people like that is to let them go their own way.

data.vi_translation: They asked me a lot of questions: Why did we cover the raft like that? Why did we rest during the day and travel at night? Is Jim the black man who is running away? I said:
data.tr_translation: The duke and the king asked us a lot of questions; they wondered why we hid on Tuesday, why we hid during the day instead of escaping â€“ or was Jim a runaway black man? â€œFor God's sake,â€ I said, â€œdo runaway negroes go south?â€
data.es_translation: THEY ASKED us a bunch of questions; they wanted to know why we were hiding the raft like that and resting during the day instead of moving forward: Was Jim a runaway slave? I answered: â€”For God's sake!

data.en: I had the middle watch, you know, but I was pretty sleepy by that time, so Jim he said he would stand the first half of it for me; he was always mighty good that way, Jim was. I crawled into the wigwam, but the king and the duke had their legs sprawled around so there warnâ€™t no show for me; so I laid outsideâ€”I didnâ€™t mind the rain, because it was warm, and the waves warnâ€™t running so high now. About two they come up again, though, and Jim was going to call me; but he changed his mind, because he reckoned they warnâ€™t high enough yet to do any harm; but he was mistaken about that, for pretty soon all of a sudden along comes a regular ripper and washed me overboard. It most killed Jim a-laughing. He was the easiest nigger to laugh that ever was, anyway.

data.es: Me tocaba la guardia en medio, ya sabÃ©is, pero para esa hora tenÃ­a bastante sueÃ±o, asÃ­ que Jim dijo que me harÃ­a la primera mitad; Jim siempre se portaba muy bien en ese sentido. Me metÃ­ a cuatro patas en el wigwam, pero el rey y el duque habÃ­an estirado tanto las piernas que no quedaba sitio, asÃ­ que me quedÃ© fuera; no me importaba la lluvia, porque hacÃ­a calor y ahora las olas no llegaban tan altas. Pero hacia las dos volvieron a levantarse y Jim me iba a llamar, aunque cambiÃ³ de opiniÃ³n porque calculÃ³ que no eran lo bastante altas para hacernos ningÃºn daÃ±o, pero en eso se equivocÃ³ porque muy pronto llegÃ³ una de esas enormes y me tirÃ³ al agua. Jim casi se muriÃ³ de la risa. De todas formas, era el negro que mÃ¡s se reÃ­a de todos los que he conocido.
data.vi_translation: I stood guard halfway through but got too sleepy, Jim said he would guard for me. Jim is always very good to me. I crawled into the tent, but the king and the duke were sprawled all over, leaving no room for me. I had to sleep outside the tent, despite the howling wind and rain. Around two o'clock, the waves became more violent. Jim intended to call me but decided not to because he thought the waves weren't too dangerous yet. But he was wrong, right after that, a big wave surged over my head. Jim looked at me and laughed heartily. The waves kept crashing and splashing all over me. Jim laughed so hard he almost burst. He was a black man who laughed easily, something I rarely encountered.
data.tr_translation: The second watch was mine, but I was getting really sleepy, so Jim said he could take the first half of my watch; Jim has always been such a kind-hearted person. I bent down and went inside the shelter, but I couldn't find a place for myself because the king and the duke were lying with their legs spread out; so I went back outside â€“ I didn't mind the rain because the weather was warm and the waves weren't rising that much anymore. Around two in the night, the waves rose again, Jim was about to call out to me, but then he changed his mind because he thought the waves hadn't risen enough to cause any harm yet; however, he was wrong about that, because a little later a giant wave came and knocked me into the water. Jim almost died laughing. I've never seen a black man who laughs so easily at everything in my life.
data.es_translation: It was my turn for the middle watch, you know, but by that time I was quite sleepy, so Jim said he would take the first half; Jim always behaved very well in that regard. I crawled into the wigwam on all fours, but the king and the duke had stretched out so much that there was no room left, so I stayed outside; I didn't mind the rain, because it was warm and now the waves weren't reaching as high. But around two o'clock they started rising again and Jim was going to call me, although he changed his mind because he figured they weren't high enough to do us any harm, but he was wrong because very soon one of those huge ones came and threw me into the water. Jim almost died laughing. Anyway, he was the black man who laughed the most of all those I have known.

data.en: I took the watch, and Jim he laid down and snored away; and by-and-by the storm let up for good and all; and the first cabin-light that showed, I rousted him out and we slid the raft into hiding quarters for the day.

data.vi_translation: I went out to stand guard in place of Jim. He had just laid down and was already snoring. Gradually, the storm subsided. At the first light of dawn, I woke Jim up and then steered the raft into hiding.
data.tr_translation: I took over the watch and Jim immediately lay down and started snoring; the storm was gradually dying down, and when I saw the first cabin light, I woke Jim up and we started looking for a place to hide the raft for the day.
data.es_translation: I took the watch and Jim lay down and started snoring; after a while the storm subsided and went away, and as soon as we saw the first light of a cabin, I woke him up and we hid the raft in our hiding place for the day.

Then there was a long white nightshirt with an outer coat for fighting. The king was very pleased. Then he handed the book to the king, telling him to memorize his parts.
