data.vi_translation: About three miles from where we were, there was a small town. After lunch, the duke said he had found a trick to travel during the day without any danger to Jim. He said he would go into town to take care of this matter. The king said he would go along to lend a hand. We were out of coffee, so Jim suggested I might as well take the boat with them to buy some.
data.tr_translation: There was a small town three miles down the bend; after dinner, he said he had thought of something that would allow us to travel during the day without putting Jim in danger; he would go to the town and take care of it. The King also wanted to go, hoping an opportunity might arise. We were out of coffee, so Jim said it would be good for me to get in the canoe with them and get some coffee.
data.es_translation: At the turn of a curve, there was a tiny village, and after lunch, the duke informed us that he had already thought of a way to navigate during the day without any danger to Jim; so he said he would go to the village to arrange everything. The king said he would also go to see if he could get something useful. Since we had run out of coffee, Jim and I said that we would also go with them to buy some.

data.vi_translation: The Duke said: - From today, if we want, we can travel during the day. If we meet anyone, we can tie Jim's hands and feet with a rope, place Jim in that tent, then show this paper and say that we caught him by the river. Because we don't have enough money for the boat, we have to borrow this wooden raft to go claim the reward. If we had iron chains to put on Jim, it would be better, but it doesn't fit with the story that we're too poor. So the rope is more reasonable. We all thought that the duke was really wise.
data.tr_translation: â€œAfter tonight, if you want, we can travel during the day as well,â€ said the duke. â€œIf we see someone coming, weâ€™ll tie Jimâ€™s hands and feet with rope and lay him in the shelter, show the visitors the notice, and tell them that we caught him while he was going up the river, that we borrowed this raft from our friends because we didnâ€™t have money to travel by steamboat, and that weâ€™re going to collect the reward. Although handcuffs and chains would look better, it would contradict our story of being very poor. It would be like wearing jewelry. Itâ€™s best to use rope â€“ as we always say in plays, we need to maintain consistency.â€
data.es_translation: â€”And now â€”said the dukeâ€”, starting tonight we can sail during the day if we want. When we see someone coming, we can tie Jim hand and foot with a rope and put him in the wigwam, show this leaflet and say that we captured him upriver and that we were too poor to travel on a steamboat, so our friends gave us this raft on credit and we came down to collect the reward. It would be better with handcuffs and chains, but that wouldn't fit with the story that we're so poor. That would be like putting jewelry on him. The right thing is some ropes: we have to maintain the units, as we say on stage.

data.vi_translation: The old man was drunk, swaying on the horse's saddle. He was over fifty, his face flushed red like a fighting cock's. Everyone who saw him shouted, laughed, and mocked him. He greeted back and said he would return to meet them, as he still had to go to town to kill Colonel Sherburn, and his motto was: Deal with the biggest first, then the small fry.
data.tr_translation: He was dead drunk and swaying on the saddle; a man over fifty with an almost crimson face. Everyone was calling out to him, laughing, teasing, and he was responding to the taunts, saying he was taking note of everything and would deal with each of them in turn, but at that moment he had no time to wait, because he had come to kill old Colonel Sherburn, and his golden rule was "eat the meat first, then go for the garnish."
data.es_translation: He was drunk and was wobbling in the chair; he was over fifty years old and had a very flushed face. Everyone was shouting at him and laughing and mocking him, and he mocked them back and told them that he would take care of them and kill them when their turn came, but that now he couldn't wait because he had come to town to kill old Colonel Sherburn, because his motto was: "First the meat and then the spoon stuff to finish."

data.en: And he nailed that shingle to a lath, and stood the lath up four or five foot in front of the wigwam. Jim was satisfied. He said it was a sight better than lying tied a couple of years every day, and trembling all over every time there was a sound. The duke told him to make himself free and easy, and if anybody ever come meddling around, he must hop out of the wigwam, and carry on a little, and fetch a howl or two like a wild beast, and he reckoned they would light out and leave him alone. Which was sound enough judgment; but you take the average man, and he wouldnâ€™t wait for him to howl. Why, he didnâ€™t only look like he was dead, he looked considerable more than that.

data.vi_translation: Then he hung that piece of wood on a tree branch, a few yards away from the tent. Jim was very pleased because it was better than being tied up every day, lying there trembling at every sound. The duke told Jim to rest assured, and if anyone wandered around, he should step out of the tent, pretend to be a madman, and howl like a wild animal, so people would be scared and run away immediately. That sounds good. But that's for anyone else; as for Jim, just seeing him would be enough to scare people without him having to howl. These two rascals intended to put on a show like the one they did the other day to make some extra money.
data.tr_translation: He nailed the sign to a stick and planted the stick a meter or two in front of the shelter. Jim was pleased. He said it was better to look like this than to lie tied up for several years a day and tremble at every sound he heard. The Duke told him to act very freely and comfortably, and if someone came there, all he had to do was get out of the shelter and do some crazy things, howl like a wild animal once or twice. Most likely, they would immediately flee and leave him alone. This idea seemed quite reasonable, but if you think about the average person, they probably wouldn't stay there long enough to wait for him to howl. Because Jim not only looked like he was dead, he had a much more frightening appearance.
data.es_translation: And he nailed the sign to a post and placed the post four or five feet in front of the wigwam. Jim was very happy. He said it was much better than being tied up for years and years every day and trembling every time he heard something. The duke told him to do whatever he pleased and that if anyone came snooping around, he should jump out of the wigwam and make a bit of a fuss and let out a howl or two like a wild animal, and he figured they would leave and let him be. Which was a pretty good idea; but the truth is that a normal man wouldn't wait for him to start howling. But it not only looked like he had died, but something much worse still!

data.vi_translation: Everyone was stunned, gathering around the doctor, intending to advise him not to be so harsh, and trying to explain that it was indeed Harvey because he knew everyone's names, even the names of the dogs. They kept pleading with the doctor not to do anything to harm Harvey and those poor girls. But it was useless, the doctor kept making a fuss, saying that anyone who claimed to be English but couldn't speak properly was just a fraud, a liar... The poor girls clung tightly to the king and cried. Suddenly, the doctor turned towards the girls and said:
data.tr_translation: Suddenly, everyone's face fell! They surrounded the doctor, trying to silence him, to explain what had happened, and to tell how Harvey had proven himself to be Harvey in forty different ways. He knew everyone by name, he even knew the names of the dogs. They also begged him not to hurt Harvey's and the poor girls' feelings. But none of it worked; the man continued to speak angrily and said that someone who tried to speak like an Englishman but did such a poor imitation could be nothing but a fraud and a liar. The poor girls were crying, clinging to the king; the doctor suddenly broke away from the crowd and turned to them.
data.es_translation: Well, what a commotion it caused! They gathered around the doctor and tried to calm him down by explaining everything and telling him that Harvey had proven in forty different ways that he was Harvey and knew everyone by name, even the names of the dogs, and they begged him over and over not to hurt Harvey's feelings or those of the poor girls and all that. But it was all in vain; he kept shouting and saying that if someone claimed to be English and couldn't mimic the way the English spoke better than that, it was because he was a fraud and a liar. The poor girls clung to the king and cried, and suddenly the doctor turned on them. He went and said:

data.vi_translation: Thinking so, I groped my way to their room. The hallway upstairs was pitch dark, but I still found the duke's room. I reached out and felt around, but then I suddenly remembered that it seemed the king didn't let anyone but the old man keep that money. I groped my way to the old man's room and felt around. It was too dark, there wasn't a single candle, and even if there was, I wouldn't dare light it. I had to lie here and listen to see what would happen. At that moment, I heard their footsteps approaching, so I crawled under the bed, but thinking that spot wasn't safe, I felt worried and then touched Mary Jane's clothes curtain, so I slipped right into the curtain and hid among the clothes, standing there very quietly.
data.tr_translation: Then I thought, the best thing to do is to go and search their rooms. The corridor upstairs was dark, but I found the duke's room and started feeling around; but then it dawned on me that the king wouldn't entrust that much money to someone else; so I went to his room and started searching there. However, after a while, I realized I couldn't see anything without light, and besides, lighting a candle here wasn't a smart idea. The best thing was to resort to the other way, wait for them, and listen to their conversations. At that moment, I heard footsteps coming from downstairs and made a move to get under the bed; I was just about to get in, but the bed wasn't where I expected it to be, instead, I grabbed the curtain covering Mary Jane's clothes, immediately jumped behind the curtain, and took refuge among the nightgowns, then didn't move at all.
data.es_translation: â€œSo â€”I thoughtâ€” Iâ€™m going to search their rooms.â€ Although the hallway upstairs was dark, I found the dukeâ€™s room and started rummaging with my hands, but I remembered that just as the king was, he wouldnâ€™t let anyone but himself handle the money, so I went to his room and started rummaging. But I saw that I couldnâ€™t do anything without a candle and, naturally, I didnâ€™t dare to light one. So I thought of doing the other thing: staying put and listening to what they said. Almost at that moment I heard them coming up and decided to hide under the bed; I went towards it, but it wasnâ€™t where I thought, I touched the curtain behind which Mary Janeâ€™s dresses were, so I jumped behind it, snuggled among the dresses, and stayed there very quietly.

data.en: The person coming was Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, very soft, and kneeled down and looked in; then she put up her handkerchief, and I see she begun to cry, though I couldnâ€™t hear her, and her back was to me. I slid out, and as I passed the dining-room I thought Iâ€™d make sure them watchers hadnâ€™t seen me; so I looked through the crack, and everything was all right. They hadnâ€™t stirred.

Fue junto al ataÃºd, andando despacito, se arrodillÃ³ y mirÃ³ dentro; despuÃ©s sacÃ³ el paÃ±uelo y vi que empezaba a llorar, aunque no la podÃ­a oÃ­r y me daba la espalda. data.vi_translation: The person who just walked in is Miss Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, knelt down to look inside, took out a handkerchief, and sobbed quietly, her back turned to me. I stepped outside, passing through the dining room, to make sure that the people keeping watch didn't see me, so I stopped and peered through the crack in the door. They didn't move at all, which was reassuring.
data.tr_translation: The person who came was Mary Jane. She quietly went to the side of the coffin, bent down and looked inside; then she took out her handkerchief and I saw that she started crying, but she made no sound and her back was turned to me. I immediately left there quietly and after passing through the dining room and closing the door behind me, I looked through the crack in the door to make sure the guards hadn't seen me. Everything seemed to be fine. They hadn't moved at all.
data.es_translation: The one who entered was Mary Jane. She went to the coffin, walking slowly, knelt down and looked inside; then she took out her handkerchief and I saw that she started to cry, although I couldn't hear her and she had her back to me. I came out of my hiding place and as I passed by the dining room I thought of making sure that those at the wake hadn't seen me, so I looked through a crack and everything was in order. They hadn't even moved.

data.en: I slipped up to bed, feeling ruther blue, on accounts of the thing playing out that way after I had took so much trouble and run so much resk about it. Says I, if it could stay where it is, all right; because when we get down the river a hundred mile or two I could write back to Mary Jane, and she could dig him up again and get it; but that ainâ€™t the thing thatâ€™s going to happen; the thing thatâ€™s going to happen is, the money â€™ll be found when they come to screw on the lid. Then the king â€™ll get it again, and it â€™ll be a long day before he gives anybody another chance to smouch it from him. Of course I wanted to slide down and get it out of there, but I dasnâ€™t try it. Every minute it was getting earlier now, and pretty soon some of them watchers would begin to stir, and I might get catchedâ€”catched with six thousand dollars in my hands that nobody hadnâ€™t hired me to take care of. I donâ€™t wish to be mixed up in no such business as that, I says to myself.

data.es: Me fui a la cama, bastante triste, por cÃ³mo estaban saliendo las cosas despuÃ©s de haberme preocupado yo tanto y haber corrido tantos peligros. Me dije: Â«Si pudiera quedarse donde estÃ¡, muy bien; porque cuando lleguemos al rÃ­o, a cien o doscientas millas, podrÃ­a escribir a Mary Jane y ella podrÃ­a desenterrarlo y sacarlo, pero eso no es lo que va a pasar; lo que va a pasar es que encontrarÃ¡n el dinero cuando vayan a cerrar la tapa. Entonces el rey volverÃ¡ a quedarse con Ã©l y no va a darle a nadie otra oportunidad de que se lo birleÂ». Naturalmente, yo querÃ­a bajar y sacarlo de allÃ­, pero no me atrevÃ­a a intentarlo. A cada minuto se acercaba el amanecer y dentro de muy poco algunos de los del velorio empezarÃ­an a moverse y quizÃ¡ me pescaran con seis mil dÃ³lares en las manos cuando nadie me habÃ­a encargado a mÃ­ del dinero. Â«Maldita la falta que me hace verme metido en una cosa asÃ­Â», me dije.
data.vi_translation: I went back to bed, still scared because of what I had just done, arduous and dangerous. I planned that when we traveled about a hundred miles downstream, I could write a letter to inform Miss Mary Jane, and she could dig up the grave to retrieve the money. But what if things didn't go as planned, and when they closed the coffin, they discovered the money hidden inside? In that case, the king would get it again, and I wouldn't have a chance to retrieve it. At this moment, I wanted to crawl down and get the money bag out. But I didn't dare to leave anymore. The sky was gradually getting brighter. The people keeping watch had started to wake up. If I went down again, I could very likely get caught with six thousand dollars in hand. It's best not to get involved in that matter anymore.
data.tr_translation: I quietly went up to the attic and lay down on my bed feeling downcast; despite getting myself into so much trouble and taking so many risks, it hadn't turned out well. As long as the bag stayed where it was, there was no problem; because after the river flowed down about a hundred miles, I could write a letter to Mary Jane and have her dig up the grave to get the money; but that's not how it would go, they would find the money when they closed the lid. Then the king would get hold of the money again and wouldn't let anyone near it. Of course, I very much wanted to go down and get the bag from there, but I just couldn't muster the courage. Morning was approaching and some of the guards might wake up, and I would get caught â€“ and I would get caught with six thousand dollars that no one had allowed me to take. I thought to myself, I would never want to be in such a situation.
data.es_translation: I went to bed, quite sad, because of how things were turning out after I had worried so much and taken so many risks. I said to myself: "If it could stay where it is, very well; because when we get to the river, a hundred or two hundred miles away, I could write to Mary Jane and she could dig it up and take it out, but that's not what's going to happen; what's going to happen is that they'll find the money when they go to close the lid. Then the king will get it again and won't give anyone else a chance to steal it." Naturally, I wanted to go down and take it out of there, but I didn't dare try. Every minute dawn was approaching and very soon some of the people from the wake would start moving and maybe catch me with six thousand dollars in my hands when no one had entrusted me with the money. "Damn the need for me to get involved in something like this," I said to myself.

data.en: When I got down stairs in the morning the parlor was shut up, and the watchers was gone. There warnâ€™t nobody around but the family and the widow Bartley and our tribe. I watched their faces to see if anything had been happening, but I couldnâ€™t tell.

data.vi_translation: In the morning, I went downstairs to find the living room door closed, and the guards had all left. Only the household members, the widow Barley, and us remained. I carefully examined their faces to see if there were any changes, but I saw nothing different.
data.tr_translation: When I went downstairs in the morning, the living room was closed and the guards were gone. Apart from the family members, the widow Mrs. Bartley, and our own people, there was no one else around. I examined their faces to see if anything had happened, but I couldn't understand anything.
data.es_translation: When I came down in the morning, the living room was closed and the people from the wake had left. There was no one left but the family, the widow Bartley, and our tribe. I looked at their faces to see if anything had happened, but I couldn't see anything.

data.en: Well, the funeral sermon was very good, but pison long and tiresome; and then the king he shoved in and got off some of his usual rubbage, and at last the job was through, and the undertaker begun to sneak up on the coffin with his screw-driver. I was in a sweat then, and watched him pretty keen. But he never meddled at all; just slid the lid along as soft as mush, and screwed it down tight and fast. So there I was! I didnâ€™t know whether the money was in there or not. So, says I, sâ€™pose somebody has hogged that bag on the sly?â€”now how do I know whether to write to Mary Jane or not? Sâ€™pose she dug him up and didnâ€™t find nothing, what would she think of me? Blame it, I says, I might get hunted up and jailed; Iâ€™d better lay low and keep dark, and not write at all; the thingâ€™s awful mixed now; trying to better it, Iâ€™ve worsened it a hundred times, and I wish to goodness Iâ€™d just let it alone, dad fetch the whole business!

data.es: Bueno, el sermÃ³n funerario resultÃ³ muy bien, pero horriblemente largo y cansado; despuÃ©s se metiÃ³ el rey y soltÃ³ unas cuantas de sus tonterÃ­as de costumbre, y por fin terminÃ³ el asunto y el enterrador se acercÃ³ al ataÃºd con su destornillador. Yo me puse a sudar y lo mirÃ© muy atento. Pero no vio nada, se limitÃ³ a correr la tapa, suave como si estuviera engrasada, y la atornillÃ³ bien atornillada. Â¡AsÃ­ estÃ¡bamos! No sabÃ­a si el dinero estaba allÃ­ dentro o no. Entonces me dije: Â«Â¿Y si alguien se ha llevado la bolsa a escondidas? Â¿Como sÃ© yo si escribir a Mary Jane o no? Â¿Y si lo desentierra y no encuentra nada, quÃ© va a pensar de mÃ­? Dita seaÂ», me dije, Â«lo mismo me buscan y me encierran: mÃ¡s me vale quedarme bien calladito y no escribir nada; ahora todo estÃ¡ hecho un lÃ­o y por tratar de mejorarlo lo he dejado cien veces peor que antes; ojalÃ¡ lo hubiera dejado todo en paz. Â¡Maldito sea todo el asunto!Â»
data.vi_translation: The pastor's sermon was good but too long. Then, after that, the king came out and babbled for a while. When everything was done, the funeral director approached the coffin with a wrench to tighten the screws. At that moment, I was very nervous, my eyes fixed on the funeral director. But he just slowly and gently lowered the lid, then tightened the screws very firmly. That's it! I wondered what if someone deceitful had already taken the money bundle out? Should I write a letter to Mary Jane? What if I write it and she digs up the grave and finds nothing, what would she think of me? I might even end up in jail. It's better not to write anything at all. Everything in my head was now all mixed up. The more I thought about it, the more complicated it seemed, so I decided to just let it be.
data.tr_translation: The funeral ceremony went very well, but it was still long and boring. Finally, the king also approached the coffin and offered a bunch of his usual nonsense, and when he was done, the undertaker approached the coffin with his screwdriver. That's when I got anxious and started watching him closely. But he didn't dawdle at all; he just closed the lid very slowly and tightened the screws well. Look at this situation! I didn't know if the money was in the coffin. What if someone took the bag without anyone noticing, I thought...How would I know whether or not to write to Mary Jane now? Let's say she dug up the grave and found nothing...What would she think about me? Damn, I could get caught and thrown in jail; the best thing was to keep quiet and not draw too much attention, not to write any letters; things had gotten really messed up; I had made things worse while trying to fix them, I wished I had never gotten involved, I was truly a thousand times regretful!
data.es_translation: Well, the funeral sermon turned out very well, but horribly long and tiring; then the king got up and spouted some of his usual nonsense, and finally the affair ended and the undertaker approached the coffin with his screwdriver. I started sweating and watched him very closely. But he didn't see anything, he just slid the lid, smooth as if it were greased, and screwed it down tight. That's how we were! I didn't know if the money was in there or not. Then I said to myself: "What if someone has secretly taken the bag? How do I know whether to write to Mary Jane or not? And if he digs it up and finds nothing, what will he think of me? Darn it," I said to myself, "they might as well look for me and lock me up: I'd better keep my mouth shut and not write anything; now everything is a mess and by trying to improve it I've made it a hundred times worse than before; I wish I had left everything alone. Damn the whole affair!

data.en: The king he visited around in the evening, and sweetened everybody up, and made himself ever so friendly; and he give out the idea that his congregation over in England would be in a sweat about him, so he must hurry and settle up the estate right away and leave for home. He was very sorry he was so pushed, and so was everybody; they wished he could stay longer, but they said they could see it couldnâ€™t be done. And he said of course him and William would take the girls home with them; and that pleased everybody too, because then the girls would be well fixed and amongst their own relations; and it pleased the girls, tooâ€”tickled them so they clean forgot they ever had a trouble in the world; and told him to sell out as quick as he wanted to, they would be ready. Them poor things was that glad and happy it made my heart ache to see them getting fooled and lied to so, but I didnâ€™t see no safe way for me to chip in and change the general tune.

data.es: El rey estuvo viendo a mucha gente aquella tarde, tranquilizando a todos, muy amistoso, y les dio a entender que en Inglaterra sus feligreses estarÃ­an preocupados por Ã©l, asÃ­ que tenÃ­a que darse prisa y resolver inmediatamente lo de la herencia antes de marcharse. Lamentaba mucho tener tantas prisas, y lo mismo les pasaba a los demÃ¡s; querÃ­an que se quedara mÃ¡s tiempo, pero decÃ­an que entendÃ­an que era imposible. Y dijo que naturalmente William y Ã©l se llevarÃ­an a las chicas a casa con ellos, lo cual tambiÃ©n agradÃ³ mucho a todos, porque entonces las chicas estarÃ­an bien protegidas y entre sus propios parientes, y tambiÃ©n agradÃ³ a las chicas; les gustÃ³ tanto que prÃ¡cticamente se olvidaron de que tenÃ­an algÃºn problema en el mundo y le dijeron que lo vendiera todo en cuanto quisiera, que ellas estaban dispuestas. Las pobrecillas estaban tan contentas y felices que me dolÃ­a el corazÃ³n de ver cÃ³mo las engaÃ±aban y las mentÃ­an tanto, pero no veÃ­a una forma segura de intervenir y hacer que cambiara el estado general de cosas.
data.vi_translation: In the evening, the king visited familiar people, pretending to be friendly. The old man said that his parishioners in England were eagerly waiting for him, so he had to quickly arrange and settle everything to return. The old man said he regretted having to rush like that. Everyone said the same, they wished he could stay longer. The old man also said that he and William would take those nieces back to their country. Hearing that, everyone was happy for the girls who would have relatives to rely on. The girls were also delighted to hear him say that. The girls urged him to sell the house and land quickly. The more joyful they were, the more heartbroken I felt seeing them being deceived. But I had no way to change the situation.
data.tr_translation: When evening came, the king walked around, spoke sweet words to everyone, and acted friendly; meanwhile, he hinted in various ways that his congregation in England was eagerly waiting for him, so he had to hurry, sell off the properties, and return home. He was sad because he had so little time, and the townspeople were very upset too; they were hoping he would stay longer, but they could understand why that wasn't possible. Of course, he and William would take the girls home with them; this made everyone happy because the girls would be taken care of, they would be with their relatives; the girls were also happy about this â€“ they were very delighted because they could start a new chapter in their lives and forget their previous troubles; they told him to sell the properties as quickly as possible, they would be ready. The poor things were so joyful and happy that it broke my heart to see them being deceived and lulled with lies, but I couldn't think of a safe way to intervene and change everything.
data.es_translation: The king was seeing a lot of people that afternoon, reassuring everyone, very friendly, and he made them understand that in England his parishioners would be worried about him, so he had to hurry and immediately resolve the inheritance issue before leaving. He regretted very much having to rush, and the same was true for the others; they wanted him to stay longer, but they said they understood that it was impossible. And he said that naturally William and he would take the girls home with them, which also pleased everyone a lot, because then the girls would be well protected and among their own relatives, and it also pleased the girls; they liked it so much that they practically forgot they had any problems in the world and told him to sell everything whenever he wanted, that they were ready. The poor girls were so happy and content that it broke my heart to see how they were being deceived and lied to so much, but I couldn't see a safe way to intervene and change the general state of things.

data.vi_translation: Then the old man laughed loudly, and everyone else laughed along, except for three or four people who did not agree. One of those people was the doctor. The second person was a very polite man, carrying a suitcase, who had just disembarked from the ship earlier and was speaking quietly with the doctor, occasionally looking up at the king and nodding their heads. That was lawyer Levi Ben, who had just returned from Louisville. The third person was large and muscular, who had just arrived and was listening to the old man earlier and now listening to the king. After the king finished speaking, that person looked up and asked:
data.tr_translation: He laughed again; the others joined him, but three or four people, maybe six or so, did not laugh. One of them was a doctor; the other was a stern-looking man carrying an old-fashioned cloth bag made of kilim. He had just gotten off the ferry and was whispering with the doctor; occasionally they would look at the king and nod their heads â€“ this man was Levi Bell, the lawyer who had gone to Louisville; there was also a burly man who came and listened to everything the old gentleman said, and now he was listening to what the king was saying. When the king finished his words, the burly man called out to him loudly:
data.es_translation: So he laughed again, just like everyone else, except three or four, or maybe half a dozen. One of them was the doctor, another a gentleman with a shrewd appearance, carrying one of those old-fashioned carpet bags, who had just disembarked from the steamboat and was speaking quietly with the doctor, while they occasionally glanced at the king and nodded: it was Levi Bell, the lawyer who had gone to Louisville, and another was a tall, sturdy fellow who had approached to hear what the old man was saying and was now listening to the king. And when the king finished, the sturdy fellow goes and says:

data.es: Bueno, Â¿quÃ© os voy a contar? El tozudo del viejo idiota no estaba dispuesto a confesar ni entonces. De verdad que no. Dijo que aquella prueba no era justa. Dijo que su hermano William se pasaba el tiempo bromeando y no habÃ­a intentado escribir, y que estaba seguro de que William iba a gastar una de sus bromas en cuanto cogiera el papel. data.vi_translation: As he spoke, he turned towards the king and the duke. At this point, the old man still wouldn't admit defeat. He said that William was a stubborn and playful person, that when he put pen to paper it was just one of his pranks. Then the old man rambled on for a while until he thought he was actually talking about himself.
data.tr_translation: Yes, in this situation, what do you think our mule-brained old fool did? He still wouldn't give up, you say, right? Indeed, he didn't give up. He said this was an unfair test. He said his brother William was the most incorrigible jester in the world, he hadn't even tried to write properly... In fact, he had sensed that the moment a pen and paper were placed in front of William, he would make one of his jokes again. He gradually opened up and continued to babble, eventually even starting to believe what he was saying himself â€“ but soon the new old gentleman interrupted:
data.es_translation: Well, what can I tell you? The stubborn old fool wasn't willing to confess even then. Really, he wasn't. He said that the test wasn't fair. He said that his brother William spent his time joking around and hadn't tried to write, and that he was sure William was going to play one of his jokes as soon as he picked up the paper. And he kept getting more heated and talking so much that he started to believe what he was saying himself; but soon the new gentleman interrupted him, and said:

data.en: At last they got out the coffin and begun to unscrew the lid, and then such another crowding and shouldering and shoving as there was, to scrouge in and get a sight, you never see; and in the dark, that way, it was awful. Hines he hurt my wrist dreadful pulling and tugging so, and I reckon he clean forgot I was in the world, he was so excited and panting.

data.es: Por fin sacaron el ataÃºd y empezaron a desatornillar la tapa, y la gente se amontonÃ³ tanto dÃ¡ndose codazos y empujones para coger sitio y mirar lo que pasaba como nunca he visto en mi vida, y aquello, en medio de la oscuridad, resultaba terrible. Hines me hizo mucho daÃ±o en la muÃ±eca a fuerza de tirar de ella, y calculo que se habÃ­a olvidado de mi existencia, de nervioso y jadeante que estaba.
data.vi_translation: Finally, they managed to lift the coffin and pry out the nails sealing the lid. Everyone tried to jostle each other to get a look inside. It was horrifying; Hines kept gripping my wrist and pulling me along. I thought he would forget about me there, as he was also intently watching.
data.tr_translation: Finally, they reached the coffin and began to remove the lid. In the crowd, there was a new wave of squeezing, elbowing, and pushing; everyone wanted to get closer and see the coffin; we were in a terrible state in that darkness. Hines was pulling my wrist so hard that it hurt a lot; he was probably so excited and curious that he had forgotten I even existed.
data.es_translation: They finally took out the coffin and began to unscrew the lid, and the crowd jostled and shoved so much to get a spot and see what was happening like I had never seen in my life, and that, in the middle of the darkness, was terrifying. Hines hurt my wrist a lot by pulling on it, and I reckon he had forgotten about my existence, as nervous and panting as he was.

data.en: So the king sneaked into the wigwam and took to his bottle for comfort, and before long the duke tackled his bottle; and so in about a half an hour they was as thick as thieves again, and the tighter they got, the lovinger they got, and went off a-snoring in each otherâ€™s arms. They both got powerful mellow, but I noticed the king didnâ€™t get mellow enough to forget to remember to not deny about hiding the money-bag again. That made me feel easy and satisfied. Of course when they got to snoring we had a long gabble, and I told Jim everything.

data.es: AsÃ­ que el rey volviÃ³ al wigwam y buscÃ³ compaÃ±Ã­a en su botella, y poco despuÃ©s el duque empezÃ³ a darle a la suya, y al cabo de una media hora volvÃ­an a estar tan amigos, y cuanto mÃ¡s amigos mÃ¡s cariÃ±osos, hasta que quedaron roncando, abrazados el uno al otro. Los dos se pusieron muy parlanchines, pero vi que el rey no lo estaba tanto como para olvidarse de que no tenÃ­a que repetir que no habÃ­a sido Ã©l quien habÃ­a escondido la bolsa con el dinero. Aquello me hizo sentir tranquilo y satisfecho. Naturalmente, cuando se pusieron a roncar nosotros estuvimos hablando mucho rato y se lo contÃ© todo a Jim.
data.vi_translation: So the king crawled into the tent, grabbed a bottle of wine, and took a swig. Then the duke also grabbed another bottle. About half an hour later, the two scoundrels were friendly with each other again as usual, hugging each other to sleep, snoring loudly. Both of them calmed down, but I noticed that the king wasn't quite at ease yet about not being able to deny hiding the bundle of money. That made me very pleased. We waited until they were snoring loudly, then we sat down and talked to each other, and I recounted the entire story to Jim.
data.tr_translation: And don't ever talk to me about making up for anything ever again in your life!â€ The king quietly took the bottle of liquor and went into the shelter; soon after, the duke also started drinking from his own bottle; about half an hour later, they were on good terms again, even their bonds had strengthened and become more affectionate; they fell asleep in each other's arms and started snoring. Both of them seemed to be in high spirits, but the king didn't get drunk enough to deny hiding the money bag again. This made me feel more at ease and happy. When they started snoring, Jim and I, of course, talked for a long time, and I told him everything.
data.es_translation: So the king went back to the wigwam and sought company in his bottle, and shortly after the duke started on his, and after about half an hour they were friends again, and the more friendly they got, the more affectionate they became, until they ended up snoring, embraced with each other. The two became very talkative, but I saw that the king wasn't so far gone as to forget that he shouldn't repeat that he wasn't the one who had hidden the bag with the money. That made me feel calm and satisfied. Naturally, when they started snoring, we talked for a long time and I told Jim everything.

data.en: And at last they took a change and begun to lay their heads together in the wigwam and talk low and confidential two or three hours at a time. Jim and me got uneasy. We didnâ€™t like the look of it. We judged they was studying up some kind of worse deviltry than ever. We turned it over and over, and at last we made up our minds they was going to break into somebodyâ€™s house or store, or was going into the counterfeit-money business, or something. So then we was pretty scared, and made up an agreement that we wouldnâ€™t have nothing in the world to do with such actions, and if we ever got the least show we would give them the cold shake and clear out and leave them behind. Well, early one morning we hid the raft in a good, safe place about two mile below a little bit of a shabby village named Pikesville, and the king he went ashore and told us all to stay hid whilst he went up to town and smelt around to see if anybody had got any wind of the Royal Nonesuch there yet. (â€œHouse to rob, you mean,â€ says I to myself; â€œand when you get through robbing it youâ€™ll come back here and wonder what has become of me and Jim and the raftâ€”and youâ€™ll have to take it out in wondering.â€) And he said if he warnâ€™t back by midday the duke and me would know it was all right, and we was to come along.

data.es: Por fin empezaron a cambiar y se pusieron a hablar en el wigwam en tono bajo y confidencial dos o tres horas seguidas. Jim y yo nos pusimos nerviosos. No nos gustaba aquello. Pensamos que estarÃ­an estudiando alguna faena peor que las anteriores. Lo hablamos muchas veces y por fin decidimos que iban a atracar la casa o la tienda de alguien o que pensaban falsificar dinero, o algo parecido. Entonces nos dio mucho miedo y decidimos que no tendrÃ­amos nada que ver con aquello, y que si se presentaba la menor oportunidad nos despedirÃ­amos a la francesa y los abandonarÃ­amos. Bueno, una maÃ±ana a primera hora escondimos la balsa en un buen sitio a seguro, a unas dos millas por debajo de una aldea que se llamaba Pikesville, y el rey fue a tierra y nos dijo a todos que siguiÃ©ramos escondidos mientras Ã©l iba al pueblo a ver si alguien se habÃ­a enterado ya de lo que era Â«La Realeza Sin ParÂ» (Â«una casa que robar, a eso te refieresÂ», me dije yo, Â«y cuando termines de robarla vas a volver y te vas a preguntar quÃ© ha sido de mÃ­ y de Jim y de la balsa, y ya puedes esperarnos sentadosÂ»). Y dijo que si no volvÃ­a al mediodÃ­a, el duque y yo sabrÃ­amos que todo iba bien y tendrÃ­amos que reunirnos con Ã©l.
data.vi_translation: In the end, they huddled together and discussed something for two or three hours, looking very secretive. Jim and I were worried, surely they were plotting something nefarious again. After thinking for a while, we guessed that they were planning to break into a house or a shop, or perhaps they were about to counterfeit money. So we got really scared and agreed that we would definitely not get involved in their actions, and if possible, we would run away immediately. One early morning, we hid the raft in a safe place, two miles away from a shabby village named Pikesville. The Duke went ashore, instructing us to hide and wait for him to go to town to see if there was any gossip about the Royal Nonesuch performance. He said that if he didn't return by noon, the Duke and I would follow him.
data.tr_translation: After a while, things started to change; every day, they would huddle together in the shelter for two or three hours, whispering secretly. Jim and I were on edge. Their intentions didn't seem very good. We thought they were making a more diabolical plan than ever. After talking amongst ourselves many times, we decided that they were either going to rob someone's house or shop, or maybe even print counterfeit money. We were both scared of this, and we swore that we would never get involved in such crimes, even if it killed us; at the first opportunity, we would get rid of them and immediately escape, leaving them behind. In the morning, we hid our raft in a safe place about two miles down from a rundown town called Pikesville; the king went ashore and told us to hide until he scouted the town to see if there was any news of the Royal Nonesuch here. ("That means until you find a house to rob," I muttered; "then you'll come back here after robbing the house, and when you don't see anyone, you'll wonder what happened to me, Jim, and the raft... wonder all you want.") The king also said that if he didn't return by noon, the duke and I should understand that everything was fine and go into town.
data.es_translation: Finally, they started to change and began talking in the wigwam in a low and confidential tone for two or three hours straight. Jim and I got nervous. We didn't like it. We thought they were planning something worse than before. We talked about it many times and finally decided that they were going to rob someone's house or store, or that they were planning to counterfeit money, or something similar. Then we got really scared and decided that we wouldn't have anything to do with it, and that if the slightest opportunity arose, we would sneak away and abandon them. Well, one early morning we hid the raft in a good, safe spot, about two miles below a village called Pikesville, and the king went ashore and told us all to stay hidden while he went to town to see if anyone had found out about "The Royal Nonesuch" ("a house to rob, that's what you mean," I said to myself, "and when you're done robbing it, you're going to come back and wonder what happened to me and Jim and the raft, and you can wait for us sitting down"). And he said that if he didn't come back by noon, the duke and I would know that everything was fine and we should meet up with him.

data.en: But there warnâ€™t no answer, and nobody come out of the wigwam. Jim was gone! I set up a shoutâ€”and then anotherâ€”and then another one; and run this way and that in the woods, whooping and screeching; but it warnâ€™t no useâ€”old Jim was gone. Then I set down and cried; I couldnâ€™t help it. But I couldnâ€™t set still long. Pretty soon I went out on the road, trying to think what I better do, and I run across a boy walking, and asked him if heâ€™d seen a strange nigger dressed so and so, and he says:

Entonces me sentÃ© y me echÃ© a llorar; no pude evitarlo. Pero no me pude quedar sentado mucho tiempo. Al cabo de un rato volvÃ­ al camino tratando de pensar lo que tendrÃ­a que hacer, me encontrÃ© con un muchacho que iba andando y le preguntÃ© si habÃ­a visto a un negro desconocido vestido de tal y tal forma, y Ã©l va y dice:
data.vi_translation: But there was no answer, and no one came out of the tent. Jim was gone! I called out loudly once, then again - and again; ran in all directions into the forest, howling, shouting, but it was useless - Jim was lost. I sat down and sobbed uncontrollably. After a while, I returned to the main road, thinking about what to do next. Suddenly, I saw a boy coming from somewhere, and I asked if he had seen a black man dressed like that. He replied:
data.tr_translation: But there was no answer, and no one came out of the shelter. Jim was not there! I called out in case he could hearâ€¦ I called again, and then again; I ran frantically back and forth in the forest, but it was no use â€“ our Jim had disappeared. I sat down and started to cry, I couldn't help it. But I couldn't sit for long. After a while, I set off thinking about what I could do, and on the way, I came across a boy and asked him if he had seen a strange-looking black man dressed like this and that.
data.es_translation: But no one answered me nor came out of the wigwam. Jim had disappeared! I shouted once, then again and again, and started running through the forest up and down, shouting and yelling, but it was all for nothing: Jim had disappeared. Then I sat down and started to cry; I couldn't help it. But I couldn't stay sitting for long. After a while, I went back to the path trying to think about what I should do, and I met a boy who was walking by and asked him if he had seen a strange black man dressed in such and such a way, and he goes and says:

data.en: I felt good and all washed clean of sin for the first time I had ever felt so in my life, and I knowed I could pray now. But I didnâ€™t do it straight off, but laid the paper down and set there thinkingâ€”thinking how good it was all this happened so, and how near I come to being lost and going to hell. And went on thinking. And got to thinking over our trip down the river; and I see Jim before me all the time: in the day and in the night-time, sometimes moonlight, sometimes storms, and we a-floating along, talking and singing and laughing. But somehow I couldnâ€™t seem to strike no places to harden me against him, but only the other kind. Iâ€™d see him standing my watch on top of hisâ€™n, â€™stead of calling me, so I could go on sleeping; and see him how glad he was when I come back out of the fog; and when I come to him again in the swamp, up there where the feud was; and such-like times; and would always call me honey, and pet me and do everything he could think of for me, and how good he always was; and at last I struck the time I saved him by telling the men we had small-pox aboard, and he was so grateful, and said I was the best friend old Jim ever had in the world, and the only one heâ€™s got now; and then I happened to look around and see that paper.

data.es: Me sentÃ­ bien y limpio de pecado por primera vez en toda mi vida y comprendÃ­ que ahora ya podÃ­a rezar. Pero no lo hice inmediatamente, sino que puse la hoja de papel a un lado y me quedÃ© allÃ­ pensando: pensando lo bien que estaba que todo hubiera ocurrido asÃ­ y lo cerca que habÃ­a estado yo de perderme y de ir al infierno. Y seguÃ­ pensando. Y me puse a pensar en nuestro viaje rÃ­o abajo yvi a Jim delante de mÃ­ todo el tiempo: de dÃ­a y de noche, a veces a la luz de la luna, otras veces en medio de tormentas, y cuando bajÃ¡bamos flotando, charlando y cantando y riÃ©ndonos. Pero no sÃ© por quÃ© parecÃ­a que no encontraba nada que me endureciese en contra de Ã©l, sino todo lo contrario. Le vi hacer mi guardia ademÃ¡s de la suya, en lugar de despertarme, para que yo pudiera dormir mÃ¡s, y vi cÃ³mo se alegrÃ³ cuando yo volvÃ­ en medio de la niebla, y cuando volvimos a encontrarnos otra vez en el pantano, allÃ¡ lejos donde la venganza de sangre, y todos aquellos momentos, y cÃ³mo siempre me llamaba su niÃ±o y me acariciaba y hacÃ­a todo lo que podÃ­a por mÃ­, y lo bueno que habÃ­a sido siempre, hasta que lleguÃ© al momento en que lo habÃ­a salvado cuando les dije a los hombres que tenÃ­amos la viruela a bordo y lo agradecido que estuvo y que habÃ­a dicho que yo era el mejor amigo que tenÃ­a en el mundo el viejo Jim, y el Ãºnico que tiene ahora, y despuÃ©s, cuando miraba al azar de un lado para el otro, vi la hoja de papel.
data.vi_translation: I felt relieved as if I had just shed all my sins. And I thought now I could pray. But I didn't pray immediately; instead, I put the piece of paper down and sat thinking. Everything had gone well just when I was most desperate. I thought again about the journey with Jim along this river. Jim was always by my side, day and night, under the moon as well as in the storm. We talked, laughed, and sang on the raft drifting along the water. I couldn't find a single thing that made me hate Jim; on the contrary. Jim stood guard for me, and instead of waking me up, he let me sleep; Jim was happy and joyful when he saw me return safely; and Jim always called me by a dear name, indulged me, and would do anything for me. Then I remembered when I saved Jim and told the others that there was someone with smallpox on the raft, and Jim told me I was his best friend in the world. Thinking that, I looked down at the piece of paper I had just written.
data.tr_translation: I now felt as if I had done a good deed and, for the first time in my life, cleansed of sin; now I could pray. But I didn't start praying right away; I put down the paper and began to think â€“ how good it was that things had ended this way, how close I had come to going down the wrong path and ending up in hell, I had narrowly escaped at the last moment. The more I thought, the more I thought. Then I started thinking about our journey down the river; the nights, the days, sometimes in the moonlight, sometimes in the storm, the moments I spent with Jim came to mind; we had traveled down the river for so long, talked, sung songs, laughed, and had fun. But for some reason, I had no memory that would harden my heart against him; on the contrary, I remembered things that softened it. I remembered how he took my watch after his own, how he couldn't bring himself to wake me up, how happy he was when I returned from the fog, how delighted he was when we met in the swamp where there was a blood feud; many similar things came to mind; he always called me the apple of his eye, patted my head, did everything he could think of for my comfort, always treated me well; lastly, I remembered the night I saved him by telling the men there were flowers on the raft, how grateful he was, how he said I was the best friend he had in this world, even his only friend now; as I thought about these things, I looked around and saw the paper.
data.es_translation: I felt good and clean of sin for the first time in my life and understood that now I could pray. But I didn't do it immediately; instead, I put the piece of paper aside and stayed there thinking: thinking how good it was that everything had happened this way and how close I had been to losing myself and going to hell. And I kept thinking. And I started thinking about our journey down the river and saw Jim in front of me all the time: day and night, sometimes in the moonlight, other times in the middle of storms, and when we floated down, chatting and singing and laughing. But I don't know why it seemed that I couldn't find anything to harden me against him, but quite the opposite. I saw him take my watch in addition to his own, instead of waking me up, so that I could sleep more, and I saw how happy he was when I returned in the middle of the fog, and when we met again in the swamp, far away where the blood feud was, and all those moments, and how he always called me his boy and caressed me and did everything he could for me, and how good he had always been, until I reached the moment when I had saved him when I told the men that we had smallpox on board and how grateful he was and that he had said that I was the best friend he had in the world, old Jim, and the only one he has now, and then, when I looked around randomly, I saw the piece of paper.

data.en: It was awful thoughts and awful words, but they was said. And I let them stay said; and never thought no more about reforming. I shoved the whole thing out of my head, and said I would take up wickedness again, which was in my line, being brung up to it, and the other warnâ€™t. And for a starter I would go to work and steal Jim out of slavery again; and if I could think up anything worse, I would do that, too; because as long as I was in, and in for good, I might as well go the whole hog.

data.es: Eran ideas y palabras terribles, pero ya estaba hecho. AsÃ­ lo dejÃ©, y no volvÃ­ a pensar mÃ¡s en lo de reformarme. Me lo quitÃ© todo de la cabeza y dije que volverÃ­a a ser malo, que era lo mÃ­o, porque asÃ­ me habÃ­an criado, y que lo otro no me iba. Para empezar, iba a hacer lo necesario para sacar a Jim de la esclavitud, y, si se me ocurÃ­a algo peor, tambiÃ©n lo harÃ­a, porque una vez metidos en ello, igual daba ocho que ochenta.
data.vi_translation: So I tore the piece of paper to shreds. I chased away everything in my mind, and said that I would follow the wicked path because I was born that way, and could not be otherwise. I had to take action to rescue Jim from a life of slavery. If I could think of anything more wicked, I would do it too.
data.tr_translation: These were terrible thoughts and terrible words, but they had already come out of my mouth. I didn't feel like taking them back, and from that day on, I didn't even think about changing my mind. From that moment on, I pushed them all out of my mind; I would continue to sin, because this was my path, I was raised for this, I couldn't follow another path. Now, what I needed to do was find a way to free Jim from slavery again; if I had to do something worse for this, I would do it, because I was already neck-deep in this and I wouldn't be able to sleep peacefully until I finished it completely.
data.es_translation: They were terrible ideas and words, but it was already done. That's how I left it, and I didn't think about reforming anymore. I got it all out of my head and said I would go back to being bad, which was my thing, because that's how I was raised, and the other way didn't suit me. To start with, I was going to do whatever it took to get Jim out of slavery, and if I thought of something worse, I would do that too, because once you're in it, it doesn't matter if it's eight or eighty.

data.vi_translation: She hugged me tightly, tears streaming down. Hugging and shaking weren't enough, she kept talking nonstop: - You don't resemble your mother as much as I thought. But thank God, I'm so happy to see you! I just want to give you a big hug! Kids, this is your cousin Tom! Say hello to him!
data.tr_translation: As soon as the woman caught me, she took me into her arms; then she started shaking both of my hands; tears were streaming down her cheeks; it seemed like she couldn't get enough of hugging and shaking my hand. "You don't look as much like your mother as I thought, but it doesn't matter at all, I'm so glad to see you!" she said. "Oh my dear, I could just eat those cheeks of yours! Kids, your cousin Tom is here!.. Say welcome to him."
data.es_translation: He hugged me and then took both of my hands and squeezed them many times, not stopping from saying: "You don't look as much like your mother as I thought, but the truth is I don't care at all. I'm so glad to see you! My God, my God, I could just eat you up! Kids, this is your cousin Tom! Come on, say hello to him.

data.en: But if they was joyful, it warnâ€™t nothing to what I was; for it was like being born again, I was so glad to find out who I was. Well, they froze to me for two hours; and at last, when my chin was so tired it couldnâ€™t hardly go any more, I had told them more about my familyâ€”I mean the Sawyer familyâ€”than ever happened to any six Sawyer families. And I explained all about how we blowed out a cylinder-head at the mouth of White River, and it took us three days to fix it. Which was all right, and worked first-rate; because they didnâ€™t know but what it would take three days to fix it. If Iâ€™d a called it a bolthead it would a done just as well.

Bueno, se me quedaron pegados dos horas, y por fin, cuando tenÃ­a la lengua tan cansada que casi no podÃ­a ni moverla, les habÃ­a dicho ya mÃ¡s cosas de mi familia (quiero decir de la familia Sawyer) de las que hubieran podido ocurrir a seis familias Sawyer juntas. Y les expliquÃ© todos los detalles de cÃ³mo se habÃ­a reventado la cabeza de un cilindro en la desembocadura del rÃ­o Blanco y nos habÃ­a llevado tres dÃ­as arreglarlo. Lo cual estaba muy bien y funcionÃ³ estupendamente, porque ellos no sabÃ­an si hacÃ­an falta tres dÃ­as para arreglarlo. Si les hubiera dicho que habÃ­amos reventado un perno les habrÃ­a dado igual.
data.vi_translation: But if they were happy one-fold, I was happy ten-fold. I felt as if I was born anew, I was joyful because I knew who I was. The past two hours, I was scared out of my wits. I also told them many more things about my family - that is, about Tom Sawyer's family. Then I recounted the story of the boiler explosion on the White River, and how I had to stay there for three days.
data.tr_translation: They were very happy, but I couldn't contain my joy; because I felt like I was reborn, I was very pleased to learn who I was. They continued with their questions for two hours; finally, my jaw was too tired to speak; I had told them so much about my family â€“ that is, the Sawyer family â€“ that it would have been enough for at least six Sawyer families. I also told them how the cylinder head blew at the mouth of the White River and how they spent three days repairing it. There was no problem here either, in fact, it was quite convincing; because they had no idea whether it would take three days to repair a cylinder head. They would probably have believed me just as much if I had said a bolt had broken.
data.es_translation: But if they were happy, that was nothing compared to me, because it was like being born again. I was overjoyed to find out who I was. Well, they stuck with me for two hours, and finally, when my tongue was so tired that I could hardly move it, I had already told them more things about my family (I mean the Sawyer family) than could have happened to six Sawyer families combined. And I explained all the details of how a cylinder head had blown at the mouth of the White River and it had taken us three days to fix it. Which was very good and worked wonderfully, because they didn't know if it took three days to fix it. If I had told them that we had blown a bolt, they wouldn't have cared.

data.es: AsÃ­ que volvimos a casa y yo ya no me sentÃ­ tan orgulloso como antes, sino como encogido y avergonzado y como si tuviera la culpa, aunque no habÃ­a hecho nada. Pero es lo que pasa siempre; no importa que uno haga las cosas bien o mal, porque la conciencia no tiene sentido comÃºn y siempre se le echa a uno encima pase lo que pase. Si yo tuviera un perro amarillo que no fuera mÃ¡s inteligente que la conciencia de las personas, lo envenenarÃ­a. Ocupa mÃ¡s espacio que todo lo demÃ¡s, y sin embargo, no sÃ© por quÃ©, no vale para nada. Tom Sawyer dice lo mismo.
data.vi_translation: We returned home, and we were no longer as eager as when we left. I felt somewhat to blame even though I had nothing to do with this incident. Whether one does right or wrong, if a person doesn't realize it, it still gnaws at them just the same. Tom Sawyer said the same thing.
data.tr_translation: We returned home, and now I felt neither cheerful like at the beginning, but base, vile, and guilty â€“ even though I had done nothing. But isn't it always like this; whether you do right or wrong changes nothing, the conscience has no logic, it aches incessantly in any case. If I had a dog as foolish as my conscience, I would poison it immediately. This wretched thing takes up more space inside a person than anything else and serves no purpose. Tom Sawyer thought the same thing.
data.es_translation: So we went back home, and I no longer felt as proud as before, but rather shrunk and ashamed and as if I were to blame, even though I hadn't done anything. But that's what always happens; it doesn't matter whether one does things right or wrong, because the conscience has no common sense and it always gets on top of you no matter what happens. If I had a yellow dog that wasn't smarter than people's conscience, I would poison it. It takes up more space than everything else, and yet, I don't know why, it's good for nothing. Tom Sawyer says the same thing.

data.vi_translation: - The black man unlocked the door when he entered, locked it again when he left, and then gave the key to Mr. Phelps. That means there is someone inside. If it's locked, it means someone is imprisoned. But it doesn't make sense that in this small plantation there would be two people imprisoned, because I see everyone is good. It's clear that Jim is imprisoned. I am determined to find Jim. Now, you come up with a plan to rescue Jim, and I'll think of another plan, then we'll see which one is better and do it.
data.tr_translation: â€œThe black man unlocked the padlock and went inside, and when he came out, he put the lock back in place. When we got up from the table, he brought my uncle a key... that was the key, I'm sure of it. The watermelon shows there was a person there, and the lock shows they were imprisoned; in such a small plantation, there probably aren't two prisoners, since everyone here gets along just fine. The prisoner is none other than our Jim. Alright... I'm glad we figured this out like detectives, otherwise, it wouldn't be any fun. Now use your brain and come up with a plan to rescue Jim, and I'll come up with one too, and we'll use whichever one we like better.â€
data.es_translation: â€”Well, the black man opened the padlock when he entered and locked it again when he left. When we got up from the table, he returned a key to the uncle, and I bet it was the same one. The watermelon indicates that he is a man; the lock, that he is imprisoned, and it is unlikely that there are two prisoners on such a small plantation where all the people are so good and so kind. The prisoner is Jim. Very well, I'm glad I figured it out like the detectives; otherwise, I wouldn't like it. Now you have to start thinking about it and come up with a plan to steal Jim; I'll come up with another one and we'll go with the one we like best.

Wouldnâ€™t that plan work?â€

data.vi_translation: I said: - My plan is like this. We go find Jim, this part is easy. Tomorrow morning, I'll retrieve my canoe hidden at the island. At night, we'll steal his keys after he goes to sleep. Then we'll head straight to the river, get Jim on the raft, hide during the day, and travel at night, just like Jim and I used to do before. Does that sound good?
data.tr_translation: â€œHere is my plan,â€ I said. â€œWe can easily find out if Jim is there or not. Tomorrow night, I'll go get my canoe, go to the island, and bring the raft. On the first moonless night, I'll wait for the old man to fall asleep, then I'll steal the key from his pocket, and Jim and I will go down the river on the raft, hiding during the day and traveling at night, just like Jim and I used to do before. Do you think this plan will work?â€
data.es_translation: â€”My plan is this â€”I saidâ€”. We can easily find out if it's Jim who is there. Then, tomorrow night I take out my canoe and we bring my raft from the island. On the first dark night we have, we take the key from the old man's pants when he goes to bed and we head down the river with Jim, hiding during the day and navigating at night, like Jim and I used to do before. Wouldn't that plan work?

data.en: Betwixt the hut and the fence, on the back side, was a lean-to that joined the hut at the eaves, and was made out of plank. It was as long as the hut, but narrowâ€”only about six foot wide. The door to it was at the south end, and was padlocked. Tom he went to the soap-kettle and searched around, and fetched back the iron thing they lift the lid with; so he took it and prized out one of the staples. The chain fell down, and we opened the door and went in, and shut it, and struck a match, and see the shed was only built against a cabin and hadnâ€™t no connection with it; and there warnâ€™t no floor to the shed, nor nothing in it but some old rusty played-out hoes and spades and picks and a crippled plow. The match went out, and so did we, and shoved in the staple again, and the door was locked as good as ever. Tom was joyful. He says;

data.vi_translation: Between the tent and the fence, there was a long roof as long as the tent, but narrower, only about one meter. The entrance door was tightly locked. Tom went to the shed, looked around, and brought back an iron bar used to pry open box lids. He used the iron bar to pry open a door. The chain fell down. We opened the door and stepped inside, then closed the door again. Striking a match, we saw that this roof was just leaning against the tent and had no passage through. Inside, there were only a few worn-out shovels and hoes. When the match went out, we stepped out, reattached the iron hook, and the door closed as before. Tom was secretly pleased. He said:
data.tr_translation: Between the fence and the shed, at the back where the shed's roof eaves met, there was a storage made of planks. It was as long as the shed, but narrow... only two meters wide. The door was at the south end and had a padlock on it. After Tom went over to the soap cauldron and did some investigating, he returned with an iron rod used to lift the lid; with this rod, he pried out one of the nails. The chain fell to the ground and we opened the door and went inside. After closing the door behind us, we lit a match to see around. The storage was only built against the wall of the shed and there was no connection between them; the floor of the storage was dirt, and inside there were only a few rusty hoes, shovels, picks, and a broken plow. When the match went out, we went outside and put the nail back in place, the door was locked as before. Tom was cheerful. â€œAlright, now it's done,â€ he said.
data.es_translation: Between the cabin and the fence, at the back, there was a shed attached to the cabin by the roof and made of wooden planks. It was as long as the cabin, but narrow: only about six meters wide. The door was on the south side and had a padlock. Tom went to the soap cauldron and started searching, and came back with that iron thing used to lift the lid, so he pried off one of the padlock's handles. The chain fell off, we opened the door and went in, closed it, and when we lit a match we saw that the shed was only built next to the cabin, with no passage to it, that it had no floor, and there was nothing but a few rusty hoes and shovels, some picks, and a broken plow. The match went out and we left and put the handle back on, so the door was closed just as well as before. Tom was delighted, and he said:

But after he got up half way about three times, and missed fire and fell every time, and the last time most busted his brains out, he thought heâ€™d got to give it up; but after he was rested he allowed he would give her one more turn for luck, and this time he made the trip.

data.vi_translation: Then we went back to the room. I entered through the back door, just had to lift the leather strap to open it, because they didn't tie it. But Tom Sawyer thought that wasn't thrilling enough, so he had to climb up the column. Three times he climbed halfway up and then slid down. The third time he fell so hard it seemed like he might have cracked his head, he decided to give up, but after thinking for a while, he climbed again. This time he made it.
data.tr_translation: We went out and headed home, I entered through the back door â€“ you just need to pull a leather strap, they don't lock the doors â€“ but for Tom Sawyer, this wasn't romantic enough: He insisted on climbing up the lightning rod. But after climbing halfway up three times and falling, and narrowly avoiding cracking his head open the last time, he started to think he might have to give up; but after resting for a while, he decided to give it one last try, hoping his luck would turn, and this time he succeeded.
data.es_translation: Then we went to the house and I entered through the back door (you just have to pull a leather cord, because they don't lock the doors there), but Tom Sawyer didn't think it was romantic enough, and the only thing that would do for him was to climb up the lightning rod. But after climbing halfway up three times and failing and falling all three times, and almost breaking his head the last time, he thought it would be better to give up, but after resting he decided he would try one more time to see how it would go, and that time he managed to make it.

When everyone had left, the key was brought down.

If Jim can do this and wants to send a simple mysterious message to let the world know where he is being held, he can scratch it onto the back of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out the window. data.es_translation: â€”Many do it with iron rust and tears, but those are the more common prisoners and women; the most authoritative authors use their own blood. Jim can do it, and when he wants to send any ordinary mysterious message so the world knows where he is captive, he can write it on the bottom of a tin plate with a fork and throw it out the window. data.vi_translation: I said: - See that? Your mind is clearer now, Tom Sawyer. Whether it's moral or not, using a hoe is still right. When I set out to steal a black man, or a watermelon, or a book from the monastery school, I don't care whether it's moral or not. What I need is my black man, what I need is my watermelon, or what I need is the book from the monastery school, and if the hoe is the most convenient, then I use the hoe. I take the hoe to dig out that black man, that watermelon, or that book, and I don't give a damn about what the reputable people think about it!
data.tr_translation: â€œNow it's done!â€ I said, â€œYour brain works better every time, Tom Sawyer. Whether it's moral or immoral, the best way is to dig; and if you ask me, I don't care about morality at all. Once you start stealing a black person, a watermelon, or a hymn book, I don't think it matters how you do it. I want my black person, I want my watermelon, or I want my hymn book; if the easiest way to get it is by digging, then I'll dig out the black person, the watermelon, or the hymn book; I don't give a damn about what the experts say on this matter.â€
data.es_translation: â€”That's the way to talk! â€”I saidâ€”. You're thinking better and better, Tom Sawyer. What matters are the picks, whether they are moral or not, and as for me, I don't give a damn about morality. When it occurs to me to steal a black person, or a watermelon, or a Sunday school book, I don't care much about how as long as I do it. What I want is my black person or my watermelon or my Sunday school book, and if the best thing is a pick, then that's what I'm going to use to get that black person, or that watermelon, or that Sunday school book, and I don't give a damn what the most authoritative authors say about it.

data.tr_translation: Upon this, I also took a shovel, and then we dug the soil using the pickaxe and the shovel in turns. We worked for another half hour, then we couldn't stand the sleeplessness anymore; but by then, we had already opened a fairly large hole. I went upstairs, and when I looked out the window, I saw Tom desperately trying to climb the lightning rod, but he couldn't manage it because his palms were blistered. â€œIt's no use, it's impossible to do this,â€ he said finally.
data.es_translation: Then I grabbed a shovel and we started digging with the pick and shovel, taking turns, like madmen. We continued like this for about half an hour, which was all we could endure; but in return, we had made a good hole. When I went upstairs, I looked out the window and saw that Tom was doing everything he could with the lightning rod, but he couldn't climb because his hands were so cracked. Finally, he said:

data.vi_translation: So the plan was going very well. Early the next morning, just as dawn was breaking, we finished writing another letter and marveled at how clever we were. By dinner time, they said that the black men would stand guard all night at both the front and back doors of the house. Tom slid down the lamp post, pasted the letter on the back of one of the black men, and climbed back up. The letter read as follows:
data.tr_translation: According to what Tom said, it was time to set off the big bomb! The next morning at dawn, we prepared another letter and started thinking about how to deliver it, because we had heard at dinner that they would station a black man at each door all night. Tom slid down the lightning rod to scout around and, finding the black man at the back door asleep, slipped the letter down his neck and returned. This letter read as follows:
data.es_translation: So, he said, let's get everything going! So the next morning, just at dawn, we prepared another letter, and we were thinking about the best way to deliver it, because at dinner time we had heard them say that they were going to put a black man on guard at each door all night. Tom went down the lightning rod to see how things were, and since the black man at the back door was asleep, he slipped it into his shirt from behind and came back. The letter said:

data.tr_translation: In one second, I reached the stairs, in the next, I slid down the lightning rod and quickly reached the shed in the dark. I was so anxious that words barely came out of my mouth, but I quickly explained everything to Tom as best as I could; we had to leave immediately, there wasn't a minute to lose... The house was filled with men, all of them armed with rifles!
data.es_translation: I went up the stairs in a second, went down the lightning rod in another, and searched for the shed in the middle of the darkness. I could barely speak because I was so worried, but I told Tom as quickly as I could that we had to get out without wasting a minute: the house was full of armed men!

data.es: En seguida se me ocurriÃ³ una idea. Me dije: Â«Â¿Y si no puede arreglarle la pierna en dos patadas, como dice el dicho? Â¿Y si le lleva tres o cuatro dÃ­as? Â¿QuÃ© vamos a hacer? EsperarÃ©, y cuando vuelva, si dice que tiene que volver, me irÃ© con Ã©l aunque sea a nado, lo atamos y nos lo llevamos rÃ­o abajo, y cuando Tom ya estÃ© curado le pagamos lo que sea, o todo lo que tengamos, y despuÃ©s le dejaremos desembarcarÂ».
data.vi_translation: I suddenly had an idea. I told myself: what if he can't cure Tom's leg right away? What if it takes three or four days to heal? What would we do? Wait there until he finishes? What should I do then? I will wait, and whenever he comes back, if he says he won't go anymore, I will go down there, swim down if necessary, we will capture and tie him up, then take him down there, and after he finishes treating Tom, we will reward him with everything we have. Then we will let him go ashore.
data.tr_translation: Before long, I started to have second thoughts. What if Tom couldn't finish treating his leg in one go, what if it took three or four days? What would we do then? Were we supposed to wait until the doctor raised a fuss? No sir, I knew exactly what I was going to do. I would wait, and if he said he needed to come back when he arrived, I would swim after him the second time; then I would trick him, tie him up, and we would take the raft and set off; once Tom was done with him, we would pay him whatever he asked, even give him everything we had in our pockets, and leave him on the shore.
data.es_translation: Then an idea occurred to me. I said to myself: "What if he can't fix his leg in a jiffy, as the saying goes? What if it takes him three or four days? What are we going to do? Wait around until he tells someone? No, sir; I know what I'm going to do. I'll wait, and when he comes back, if he says he has to return, I'll go with him even if I have to swim, we'll tie him up and take him down the river, and when Tom is healed we'll pay him whatever it takes, or everything we have, and then we'll let him disembark."

data.es: â€”Pues no tenÃ­a motivo â€”dije yoâ€”, porque estaba muy bien. Seguimos a los hombres y a los perros, pero corrieron mÃ¡s que nosotros y nos perdimos, pero creÃ­mos que los habÃ­amos oÃ­do en el agua, asÃ­ que sacamos una canoa, los seguimos y cruzamos al otro lado, pero no los vimos; entonces seguimos ribera arriba hasta que nos cansamos, dejamos atada la canoa y nos quedamos dormidos, y no nos hemos despertado hasta hace una hora; entonces vinimos remando a ver quÃ© pasaba y Sid ha ido a la oficina de correos a ver si se entera de algo y yo ando dando una vuelta a ver si consigo algo de comer antes de ir a casa.
data.vi_translation: I replied - Auntie, don't worry, we're fine. We ran after the people with the dogs, but they ran too fast, and we got lost. Then we thought we heard them by the river, so we took the boat to chase them and crossed to the other side of the river, but we still couldn't find them. Then we went ashore to rest, we were so tired, we tied the boat and took a nap, we just woke up an hour ago. After that, we rowed the boat back here to get some news. Sid ran to the post office to gather information, and I came here to find something to eat before we head home.
data.tr_translation: â€œThere was no need to panic,â€ I said, â€œbecause we are both fine. We followed the men and the dogs, but they were faster than us, so we lost them after a while; at one point, we thought the sounds were coming from the river, so we got into a canoe and went after them, we went across but saw no one; we tried to come back up the river, but we were exhausted; we tied the canoe somewhere and fell asleep and woke up just an hour ago, then came here to find out what happened, Sid went to the post office thinking someone might have heard something, and I was going to get something to eat, then we were going to come home.â€
data.es_translation: â€”Well, there was no reason â€”I saidâ€”, because it was very good. We followed the men and the dogs, but they ran faster than us and we got lost, but we thought we had heard them in the water, so we took out a canoe, followed them and crossed to the other side, but we didn't see them; then we followed the riverbank upstream until we got tired, tied up the canoe and fell asleep, and we haven't woken up until an hour ago; then we came rowing to see what was happening and Sid has gone to the post office to see if he finds out anything and I'm walking around to see if I can get something to eat before going home.

data.vi_translation: - Strange, he has to have a group of black people in there every night, working for four weeks to get that much, Mrs. Phelps. Look at that shirt, every inch of it has a secret sign written in blood by Africans! There must always be a group there, no doubt about it. I'd pay two dollars right away to anyone who can read those secret words to me, and any black person who writes for me also has to explain what it means...
data.tr_translation: â€œOh, goodness gracious, Brother Phelps, for four weeks there were probably a houseful of black people there every night, only just managing to get all that work done. Look at this shirtâ€¦ every inch of it is covered with secret African writings in blood! It must have been a raft full of black people coming to work. I'll pay two dollars to have this writing read; as for the black people who wrote it, I know exactly what I'll do to themâ€¦â€
data.es_translation: â€”Well, hang me, there must have been a whole gang of blacks who spent every night for four weeks to have done so much work, sister Phelps.
